children.label: experimental forests
children.definition: Timbered lands dedicated to research on forestry and forest management, silvicultural practices, forest ecosystems, wildlife habitats, and forest growth and development.

children.label: forest plantations
children.definition: Forest stand regenerated artificially either by sowing or planting.

children.label: demonstration forests
children.definition: Forests which provide models of forest ecology and exhibitions of various forest management techniques and silvicultural practices.

children.label: nutrient management
children.definition: Managing the amount, source, placement, form, and timing of the application of nutrients and soil amendments to ensure adequate soil fertility for plant production and to minimize the potential for environmental degradation, particularly water quality impairment.

children.label: cropping systems
children.definition: The pattern of crops grown on a given piece of land, or order in which the crops are cultivated over a fixed period.

children.label: mixed cropping
children.definition: The growing of several crops simultaneously in the same field but not in rows.

children.label: sequential cropping
children.definition: The growing of two or more crops in sequence on the same field in the same year.

children.label: intercropping
children.definition: Any pattern of planting a plant in or near other plants.

children.label: alley cropping
children.definition: A cropping system that involves growing crops in a wide strip, typically 6 meters in width, between lines of closely planted, fast-growing trees or shrubs. These woody species are usually leguminous and are pruned frequently to provide a mulching material and nutrients to the crop in the alley.

children.label: relay cropping
children.definition: The seeding of one crop into another standing crop, e.g., winter wheat into standing soybeans. A practice of starting one crop in another.

children.label: strip cropping
children.definition: The growing of crops in a systematic arrangement of strips or bands which serve as vegetative barriers to wind and water erosion. The strips or bands may run perpendicular to the slope of the land or to the direction of prevailing winds.

children.label: crop rotation
children.definition: System of cultivation where different crops are planted in consecutive growing seasons to maintain soil fertility.

children.label: double cropping
children.definition: Two different crops grown on the same area in one growing season.

children.label: sole cropping
children.definition: Growing one crop variety in pure stands on a piece of land at any one time.

children.label: ratooning
children.definition: Production of a subsequent crop that results from the regrowth from roots of the previous harvested crop, as in sugarcane, pineapple, and banana.

children.label: bioenergy cropping
children.definition: Growing crops for the production of bio-fuels.

children.label: continuous cropping
children.definition: The growing of a single crop species on a field year after year. Contrast crop rotation and mixed cropping.

children.label: sustainable agriculture
children.definition: An integrated system of plant and animal production practices having a site-specific application that will, over the long-termâ€” (A) satisfy human food and fiber needs; (B) enhance environmental quality and the natural resource base upon which the agriculture economy depends; (C) make the most efficient use of nonrenewable resources and on-farm resources and integrate, where appropriate, natural biological cycles and controls; (D) sustain the economic viability of farm operations; and (E) enhance the quality of life for farmers and society as a whole.

children.label: community supported agriculture
children.definition: Community Supported Agriculture consists of a community of individuals who pledge support to a farm operation so that the farmland becomes, either legally or spiritually, the community's farm, with the growers and consumers providing mutual support and sharing the risks and benefits of food production.

children.label: good agricultural practices
children.definition: Guidelines and methods for farmers, growers, food producers, and those involved in agriculture to manage the resources important to agriculture, such as soil, water, and air, to produce safe and hygienic food products with commitment to sustainability and conservation, while protecting human and animal health and welfare as well as the environment.

children.label: sustainable agricultural intensification
children.definition: Sustainable crop production intensification provides opportunities for optimizing crop production per unit area, taking into consideration the range of sustainability aspects including potential and/or real social, political, economic and environmental impacts.

children.label: crop diversification
children.definition: Crop diversification is defined as the strategy of shifting from less profitable to more profitable crops, changing of variety and cropping system, increasing exports and competitiveness in both domestic and international markets, protecting the environment, and making conditions favorable for combining Agriculture-Fishery-Forestry-Livestock. Crop diversification can be a useful means to increase crop output under different situations.

children.label: precision agriculture
children.definition: A management strategy that utilizes site-specific information to precisely and economically manage and optimize production inputs.

children.label: Clean Air Act
children.definition: The CAA is a federal law passed in 1970 that requires EPA to establish regulations to control the release of contaminants to the air to protect human health and environment.

children.label: Safe Drinking Water Act
children.definition: The act designed to protect the nation's drinking water supply by establishing national drinking water standards (maximum contaminant levels or specific treatment techniques) and by regulating underground injection control wells.

children.label: polluter pays principle
children.definition: The requirement that the cost of environmental damage, pollution control or remediation be borne by the person, organization or business responsible for the pollution-causing activity.

children.label: Clean Water Act
children.definition: A Federal law that controls the discharge of pollutants into surface water in a number of ways, including discharge permits.

children.label: economic sustainability
children.definition: The application of economic concepts, models, and tools to the sustainable development of resources, businesses and communities.

children.label: life cycle costing
children.definition: The life cycle cost of a product or project includes discounted costs of operation, maintenance, contracting, and disposal/decommissioning in addition to initial acquisition cost.

children.label: environmentally preferable purchasing
children.definition: Buying of renewable, environmentally-friendly or biobased products to provide benefits including climate change impact reduction, energy security and sustainable economic development.

children.label: ecolabeling
children.definition: A symbol, graphic or statement that appears on products or their packaging in order to convey an environmental aspect of that product to the consumer.

children.label: environmental product declaration
children.definition: A standardized (ISO 14025/TR) life-cycle assessment-based mechanism to communicate quantified life-cycle environmental information for a product.

children.label: product category rule
children.definition: A product category rule is a set of detailed rules, requirements, and guidelines for developing environmental declarations for a class of products. PCRs set the methods and life-cycle assessment boundary conditions that underpin an environmental product declaration.

children.label: ecological economics
children.definition: A transdisciplinary field of study that integrates environmental, social and economic systems that examines the economic values of non-market products and services where the economy is connected to, and sustained by, a flow of energy and materials in the natural environment.

children.label: eco-efficiency
children.definition: The relationship between economic outputs of products, processes and services and their environmental impact, with the goal being efficient use of materials and energy throughout the life cycle in order to reduce economic and ecological costs.

children.label: ecosystem services
children.definition: Benefits people and other organisms obtain from ecosystems; examples include: pure water and clean air, scenic landscapes, wildlife habitat and biodiversity.

children.label: administration of justice
children.definition: The practical execution of the law, including law enforcement, corrections and the judicial system.

children.label: law enforcement
children.definition: The generic name for the activities of the agencies responsible for maintaining public order and enforcing the law, particularly the activities of prevention, detection, and investigation of crime and the apprehension of criminals.

children.label: food inspection
children.definition: Examination of foods to assure wholesome and clean products free from unsafe microbes or chemical contamination, natural or added deleterious substances, and decomposition during production, processing, packaging, etc.

children.label: traceability
children.definition: The process of monitoring the movement of products from production to consumption and vice versa.

children.label: prioritization
children.definition: The ranking of activities in order of importance based on the capacity to accomplish them in a timely manner; the establishment of priority.

children.label: risk analysis
children.definition: The analytical process for assessing, managing and communicating information about potential hazards or other undesirable events, and quantifying their probability and expected consequences.

children.label: risk-benefit analysis
children.definition: Comparison of the short- and long-term risks to the overall societal benefits of an activity, chemical use, or technology. When risks and benefits are expressed in monetary terms, this is effectively cost-benefit analysis.

children.label: risk assessment
children.definition: The qualitative or quantitative evaluation of the likelihood of adverse effects. A risk assessment generally has four steps: hazard identification, hazard characterization, exposure assessment and risk characterization.

children.label: qualitative risk assessment
children.definition: A risk assessment based on data which, although insufficient for numerical risk estimations, allows risk ranking or separation into descriptive categories of risk and identification of inherent uncertainty.

children.label: probabilistic risk assessment
children.definition: Risk evaluation involving the calculation and expression of risks using multiple risk descriptors to provide the likelihood of various risk levels. Probabilistic risk results approximate a full range of possible outcomes and the likelihood of each, which often is presented as a frequency distribution graph, thus allowing uncertainty or variability to be expressed quantitatively.

children.label: quantitative risk assessment
children.definition: A risk assessment that uses numerical expressions of risk and indication of inherent uncertainty.

children.label: adverse outcome pathways
children.definition: Models connecting initiating events at the cellular and molecular level to population-wide impacts. Computational models may be at levels relating toxicology to adverse effects.

children.label: hazard identification
children.definition: The description of the types and nature of adverse effects caused by substances, activities or events.

children.label: exposure assessment
children.definition: The determination or estimation (qualitative or quantitative) of the magnitude, frequency, duration and route of exposure of a population.

children.label: exposure profile
children.definition: The analysis (qualitative or quantitative) of the magnitude, frequency, duration and route of exposure to a pathogen during a microbial risk assessment.

children.label: exposome
children.definition: The measure of all the exposures of an individual from all sources, including environmental and occupational sources, in a lifetime and how those exposures relate to health.

children.label: exposure scenario
children.definition: A set of assumptions concerning how an exposure may take place, including exposure setting, stressor characteristics, and activities that may lead to exposure.

children.label: permissible exposure limit
children.definition: Occupational Safety and Health Administration's permissible exposure limit expressed as a time-weighted average; the concentration of a substance to which most workers can be exposed without adverse effect averaged over a normal 8-h workday or a 40-h workweek.

children.label: source attribution
children.definition: The process of determining what proportion of a particular biological, chemical or physical agent is acquired from a given origin and through a given exposure pathway.

children.label: exposure models
children.definition: A mathematical, statistical or visual conceptualization of the exposure process.

children.label: time-weighted average
children.definition: The average value of a parameter (e.g., concentration of a chemical in air) that varies over time.

children.label: average daily intake
children.definition: The intake of a biological, chemical or physical agent that is averaged over a specified time period taking into account the frequency, duration, and intensity of exposure. Usually expressed in units of mg/kg/day.

children.label: exposure characterization
children.definition: A component of the exposure assessment that analyzes interactions between a pathogen, the environment and the host, resulting in an exposure profile. Steps include pathogen characterization, pathogen occurrence and exposure analysis.

children.label: pathogen occurrence
children.definition: A step in exposure characterization describing the frequency of appearance of a pathogen in the environment.

children.label: pathogen characterization
children.definition: A step in exposure characterization that examines the characteristics of a pathogen which affects its transmission and pathogenicity.

children.label: estimated exposure dose
children.definition: The measured or calculated dose to which organisms are likely to be exposed considering all sources and routes of exposure.

children.label: chemical risk assessment
children.definition: The qualitative or quantitative evaluation of the likelihood of adverse effects from chemical agents.

children.label: risk characterization
children.definition: The last phase of the risk assessment process that estimates the potential for adverse health or ecological effects to occur from exposure to a stressor and evaluates the uncertainty involved.

children.label: risk screening
children.definition: A process that separates hazard elements into descriptive categories of interest to decision makers based on specific criteria.

children.label: risk description
children.definition: A narrative that defines and limits an adverse condition for decision making.

children.label: risk ranking
children.definition: The placement of hazard elements into an ordinal sequence for decision making based on qualitatiive or quantitative information.

children.label: risk estimate
children.definition: The quantitative estimation of risk resulting from risk characterization.

children.label: release assessment
children.definition: Evaluation of the probability of introduction of an agent from its origin until the point of entry into a country or area.

children.label: comparative risk assessment
children.definition: The process of comparing and ranking various types of risks to identify priorities and influence resource allocations.

children.label: hazard characterization
children.definition: The description of adverse effects in terms of their toxicity, dose response, and exposure route, duration and timing.

children.label: risk adjustment
children.definition: The use of severity-of-illness measures, such as age, to estimate the risk (measurable or predictable chance of loss, injury or death) to which a patient is subject before receiving some health care intervention. This adjustment allows comparison of performance and quality across organizations, practitioners, and communities.

children.label: nutrition risk assessment
children.definition: The qualitative or quantitative evaluation of the likelihood of adverse effects related to nutritional status, nutrient intake, or nutritionally-related medical conditions.

children.label: microbiological risk assessment
children.definition: The qualitative or quantitative evaluation of the likelihood of adverse effects from pathogenic microorganisms.

children.label: risk assessment process
children.definition: A description of the framework, plan and course of action used to perform a risk assessment activity.

children.label: consequence assessment
children.definition: Evaluation of the biological, economic, environmental or health impacts of the introduction of an agent.

children.label: cumulative risk assessment
children.definition: An analysis, characterization, and possible quantification of the combined risks to health or the environment from multiple agents or stressors.

children.label: deterministic risk assessment
children.definition: Risk evaluation involving the calculation and expression of risks as single numerical values or "single point" estimates of risk, with uncertainty and variability discussed qualitatively.

children.label: risk management
children.definition: The process an organization undertakes to minimize financial, health or other risks by identifying potential hazards or adverse effects and by planning for and handling incidents which do occur in such a manner that their effect and cost are minimized.

children.label: risk profile
children.definition: The process of describing a problem and its context, in order to identify those elements of the hazard or risk relevant to various risk management decisions. The risk profile would include identifying aspects of hazards relevant to prioritizing and setting the risk assessment policy and aspects of the risk relevant to the choice of safety standards and management options.

children.label: risk communication
children.definition: An educational process where potential risks are communicated to individuals or groups of individuals in order to promote risk awareness and prevent adverse incidents.

children.label: crisis communication
children.definition: A type of risk communication that acknowledges a hazard, validates concern, and communicates effective action.

children.label: precaution advocacy
children.definition: A type of risk communication that aims to increase concern for a real hazard in order to motivate preventative action.

children.label: risk communication process
children.definition: A description of the framework, plan and course of action used to perform a risk communication activity.

children.label: weight-of-evidence
children.definition: A system for characterizing the extent to which the available data support the hypothesis that an agent causes an adverse health effect.

children.label: risk reduction
children.definition: Measures taken to reduce adverse effects.

children.label: risk management process
children.definition: A description of the framework, plan and course of action used to perform a risk management activity.

children.label: precautionary principle
children.definition: An approach to decision making in risk management which justifies preventive measures or policies despite scientific uncertainty about detrimental effects.

children.label: safety assessment
children.definition: An evaluation of the adverse effect of a biological, chemical or physical agent based on toxicity and exposure data; as contrasted with risk assessment, probability analysis is not involved in safety assessment.

children.label: supply chain management
children.definition: Supply chain management is the active management of supply chain activities to maximize customer value and achieve a sustainable competitive advantage. It represents a conscious effort by the supply chain firms to develop and run supply chains in the most effective & efficient ways possible. Supply chain activities cover everything from product development, sourcing, production, and logistics, as well as the information systems needed to coordinate these activities.

children.label: customer service
children.definition: Assistance provided to buyers of goods or services, such as providing technical information, complaint resolution, return of goods, etc.

children.label: corporate social responsibility
children.definition: The principle where businesses have a responsibility to make decisions that favorably impact the social, economic or environmental development of society.

children.label: best management practices
children.definition: A practice or system of practices designed to prevent or mitigate damage or adverse effects caused by farming, construction, manufacturing, or other anthropogenic activities.

children.label: needs assessment
children.definition: Systematic identification of a population's needs or the assessment of individuals to determine the proper level of services needed.

children.label: decentralization
children.definition: Distribution of powers from a central authority to a local authority.

children.label: facilities management
children.definition: Practice of coordinating the physical workplace with the workflow of an organization.

children.label: planning
children.definition: The determination of the objectives or goals of an enterprise and the selection, through a systematic consideration of alternatives, of the policies, programs and procedures for achieving them.

children.label: operations research
children.definition: The use of analytic methods adopted from mathematics for solving operational problems. Among the common scientific techniques used in operations research are mathematical programming, statistical theory, information theory, game theory, Monte Carlo methods, and queueing theory.

children.label: participatory management
children.definition: A management practice in which employees participate in management decision making within an organization.

children.label: certification
children.definition: Documentation from an authoritative body that confirms that a product, process, service, person or organization has characteristics that meet a certain standard or requirement.

children.label: certification (education)
children.definition: Receipt of documentation of the completion of a course of study which does not lead to a diploma.

children.label: governance
children.definition: The process by which a group of individuals is given authority to direct, inform, monitor and manage resources in order to achieve the objectives of a given organization or program.

children.label: audits
children.definition: Systematic, independent and objective reviews of verifiable information, documentation or records.

children.label: products and commodities
children.definition: A transportable resource product with commercial value; all resource products which are articles of commerce.

children.label: feeds
children.definition: Any non-injurious edible material having nutrient value; may be harvested forage, range or artificial pasture forage, grain, or other processed food for livestock or game animals.

children.label: silage
children.definition: Any crop that is harvested green and preserved in a succulent condition by partial fermentation in a more-or-less airtight container such as a silo.

children.label: haylage
children.definition: Low-moisture silage (35-55% moisture). Grass and legume crops are cut and wilted in the field to a lower moisture level than normal for grass silage, but the crop is not sufficiently dry for baling.

children.label: feed grains
children.definition: Any of several grains most commonly used for livestock or poultry feed, including corn, grain sorghum, oats, rye and barley.

children.label: mash feed
children.definition: A ground feed of cereals, cereal products, and sometimes supplements which may be fed in a wet or dry form to poultry and livestock.

children.label: palm oils
children.definition: Oils pressed from the pulp of the fruit of various palms (Arecaceae). The African palm (Elaeis guineensis) is a common source for palm oil. Palm oils are high in saturated fat and carotene, and used in foods, soaps, cosmetics, candles. Compare with palm kernel oil.

children.label: palm kernel oil
children.definition: The oil from the kernel or "nut" of the palm. Compare with palm oils.

children.label: chemical pulp
children.definition: Pulp made from chemically treated fibers

children.label: mechanical pulp
children.definition: Pulp that has not been cooked or chemically treated.

children.label: wood extractives
children.definition: Substances in wood, not an integral part of the cellular structure, that can be removed by solution in hot or cold water, ether, benzene, or other solvents that do not react chemically with wood components.

children.label: coconut cream
children.definition: The thick, pasty top layer which separates from coconut milk upon refrigeration or canning, and contains less water.

children.label: pomace
children.definition: The pulpy residue remaining after the juice has been pressed from fruit.

children.label: betel
children.definition: A masticatory (also known as betel quid) used in India and Southeast Asia, consisting of a piece of Areca nut (sometimes inaccurately called the betel nut) rolled up with mineral lime in a leaf of Piper betle (betel leaf). It is a stimulant and astringent, with a wide range of medicinal properties.

children.label: mustard greens
children.definition: The young, dark green leaves of mustard plants that are used as a cooked vegetable or as a salad green. The leaves have a strong, peppery taste.

children.label: mustard (condiment)
children.definition: A flavoring that comes from the ground seeds of the mustard (Brassica) plant available as a powder or a paste.

children.label: spent coffee grounds
children.definition: The waste product that remain in a pot after brewing coffee.

children.label: wood veneer
children.definition: A thin layer or sheet of wood.

children.label: wood flour
children.definition: Wood reduced to finely divided particles, approximately the same as those of cereal flours in size, appearance, and texture, and passing a 40 to 100 mesh screen.

children.label: wood-based panels
children.definition: A generic term for a material manufactured from wood veneer, strands, flakes, particles, or fibers or other lignocellulosic material and a synthetic resin or other binder.

children.label: particleboards
children.definition: Structural panel products made of wood fragments, such as chips or shavings, that are mechanically pressed into sheet form and bonded together with resin under heat and pressure.

children.label: waferboards
children.definition: A particle panel product made of wafer-type flakes. Usually manufactured to posses equal properties in all directions parallel to the plane of the panel.

children.label: flakeboards
children.definition: A generic term indicating a manufactured panel product composed of flakes bonded with a synthetic resin.

children.label: oriented strandboards
children.definition: An engineered structural wood-based panel composed of wood strands, flakes or wafers bonded under heat and pressure with a waterproof resin. The external layers are aligned in the panel direction and the inner layers are either cross-aligned or randomly-oriented. Common uses are sheathing in walls, floors, and roofs.

children.label: plywood
children.definition: A glued wood panel made up of relatively thin layers of veneer with the grain of adjacent layers at right angles or of veneer in combination with a core of lumber or of reconstituted wood. The usual constructions have an odd number of layers.

children.label: softwood plywood
children.definition: Structural material made of layers of softwood veneer glued together, under heat and pressure, with the grains of adjoining layers at right angles to each other.

children.label: fiberboards
children.definition: A generic term inclusive of panel products of various densities manufactured of refined or partially refined wood (or other lignocellulosic) fibers. Bonding agents may be added.

children.label: hardboard
children.definition: A generic term for a panel manufactured primarily from interfelted lignocellulosic fibers (usually wood), consolidated under heat and pressure in a hot press to a density of 496 kg m-3 (31 lb ft-3) or greater. May be manufactured using either a dry-process or wet-process.

children.label: medium density fiberboards
children.definition: An engineered wood product formed by breaking down softwood into wood fibres, compressing it with a binding material, such as glue, wax and resin, and forming panels by applying high temperature and pressure. These panels have a density of around 800 kg/m3.

children.label: wood beams
children.definition: A structural timber (i.e., wood which is relatively large in size, strength and stiffness) supporting a load applied transversely to it.

children.label: hardwood
children.definition: Generally one of the botanical groups of trees that have vessels or pores and broad leaves, in contrast to the conifers or softwoods. The term has no reference to the actual hardness of the wood.

children.label: pulpwood
children.definition: wood destined or suited for pulp manufacture, including standing or felled trees, logging residues, sawmill wastes, etc.

children.label: tropical wood
children.definition: Wood from a tropical or subtropical tree species.

children.label: refractory wood
children.definition: Wood that is difficult to dry, treat with preservatives or process using conventional methods.

children.label: roundwood
children.definition: solid wood that is in the round state. This term is also used for the volume of logs required to produce a given quantity of lumber, panels, pulp, paper or other wood products.

children.label: wood logs
children.definition: individual pieces of roundwood.

children.label: sawlogs
children.definition: A log large enough to be sawed economically into boards on a sawmill. Sawlogs are usually at least 8 inches in diameter at the small end.

children.label: cordwood
children.definition: Wood that is cut in short lengths, usually measured in cords and commonly used as fuel. Applies also to other products measured in cords.

children.label: recycled wood
children.definition: Any wood or wood fuel which is derived from such products or processes as pallets, skids, spools, packaging materials, bulky wood waste or scraps from newly built wood products, provided such wood is not treated wood.

children.label: softwood
children.definition: Generally, one of the botanical groups of trees that have no vessels and in most cases have needlelike or scalelike leaves, the conifers, also the wood produced by such trees. The term has no reference to the actual hardness of the wood.

children.label: lumber
children.definition: The product of the saw and planing mill for which manufacturing is limited to sawing, resawing, passing lengthwise through a standard planing machine, crosscutting to length, and matching. Lumber may be made from either softwood or hardwood

children.label: finger-jointed lumber
children.definition: An end joint made up of several meshing wedges or fingers of wood bonded together with an adhesive. Fingers are sloped and may be cut parallel to either the wide or narrow face of the piece.

children.label: finger-jointed lumber
children.definition: An end joint made up of several meshing wedges or fingers of wood bonded together with an adhesive. Fingers are sloped and may be cut parallel to either the wide or narrow face of the piece.

children.label: laminated veneer lumber
children.definition: An engineered wood product created by parallel lamination of veneers glued under heat and pressure with the grain of each veneer running parallel to the longitudinal axis of the billet.

children.label: wood trusses
children.definition: An assembly of members, such as beams, bars, rods, and the like, so combined as to form a rigid framework. All members are interconnected to form triangles.

children.label: glulam
children.definition: A manufactured structural timber product composed of layers of dimensional lumber glued together.

children.label: paperboard
children.definition: The distinction between paper and paperboard is not sharp, but broadly speaking, the thicker (greater than 0.3 mm (0.012 in.), heavier, and more rigid grades of paper are called paperboard.

children.label: wood extractives
children.definition: Substances in wood, not an integral part of the cellular structure, that can be removed by solution in hot or cold water, ether, benzene, or other solvents that do not react chemically with wood components.

children.label: grains
children.definition: The edible whole grains from plants, mostly in the grass family (Poaceae). Grain markets include soybeans as grains.

children.label: waxy corn
children.definition: A type of corn in which the starch content of kernels is high in amylopectin.

children.label: food grains
children.definition: Cereal seeds most commonly used for human food, chiefly wheat and rice.

children.label: feed grains
children.definition: Any of several grains most commonly used for livestock or poultry feed, including corn, grain sorghum, oats, rye and barley.

children.label: glutinous rice
children.definition: Rice with 0-2% amylose or mainly amylopectin in the endosperm and pollen starch.

children.label: rough rice
children.definition: Unmilled rice that still contains the husk.

children.label: brown rice
children.definition: Rice from which only the hulls have been removed revealing the brown bran layers.

children.label: black rice
children.definition: An unmilled, medium grain rice with black bran.

children.label: red rice
children.definition: An unmilled, long-grain rice with red bran.

children.label: triticale
children.definition: The grain of an intergeneric hybrid of Triticum x Secale (wheat and rye).

children.label: winter barley
children.definition: A general term for barley sown in the fall, persisting through the winter as seedlings, and harvested the following spring or summer after it reaches full maturity.

children.label: spring wheat
children.definition: A general term for wheat sown in the early spring and harvested in the late summer or early autumn of the same year.

children.label: winter wheat
children.definition: A general term for wheat sown in the fall, persisting through the winter as seedlings, and harvested the following spring or summer after it reaches full maturity.

children.label: waxy wheat
children.definition: A type of wheat in which the starch content of grains is high in amylopectin.

children.label: wheat classes
children.definition: Wheat classes are determined (1) by the hardness and color of their kernels and (2) by the time of year they are planted and harvested. These factors, along with their protein content and gluten strength, determine their milling and baking characteristics and whether the resulting wheat flours are better suited for making bread, pasta, cake or pastries. Each wheat class represents a separate market.

children.label: soft red winter wheat
children.definition: A wheat class seeded in the fall, has low to medium protein content, with a soft endosperm; and is used in making cakes, pastries, flat breads, and crackers. Grown in the eastern third of the U.S., east of the Mississippi River. It has a high yield, but relatively low protein.

children.label: hard red spring wheat
children.definition: The wheat class that contains the highest percentage of proteins, making it an excellent bread wheat, with superior milling and baking characteristics; chiefly grown in Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, and Minnesota; seeded in the spring, and may have a hard or soft endosperm.

children.label: soft white wheat
children.definition: A wheat class used much in the same way as Soft Red Winter (for bakery products other than bread). Grown mainly in the Pacific Northwest, and to a lesser extent in California, Michigan, Wisconsin, and New York, of low protein, but high yield. Produces flour for cakes, crackers, cookies, pastries, quick breads, muffins, snack foods.

children.label: hard red winter wheat
children.definition: The class of wheat used mostly for bread and all-purpose flour; seeded in the fall; ranges from medium to high in protein; may have either a hard or soft endosperm; accounts for more than 40% of the US wheat crop and more than half of US wheat exports; produced in the Great Plains. Wide range of protein, good milling and baking characteristics. Used to produce bread, rolls, and, to a lesser extent, sweet goods and all-purpose flour.

children.label: hard white wheat
children.definition: Newest white class of wheat to be grown in the U.S. Closely related to red wheats (except for color genes), this wheat has a milder, sweeter flavor, equal fiber, and similar milling and baking properties. Used in yeast breads, hard rolls, bulgur, tortillas, and oriental noodles. Used in domestic markets and exported in limited quantities.

children.label: durum wheat
children.definition: The hardest of all U.S. wheats, seeded in the spring, and contains a high amount of protein, which is good for pasta products (macaroni, spaghetti, and other noodles), grown in the same northern area as Hard Red Spring wheat--mainly in North Dakota.

children.label: bulgur
children.definition: Wheat that has been parboiled, dried, and partially debranned for later use in cracked or whole grain form.

children.label: spring wheat
children.definition: A general term for wheat sown in the early spring and harvested in the late summer or early autumn of the same year.

children.label: winter wheat
children.definition: A general term for wheat sown in the fall, persisting through the winter as seedlings, and harvested the following spring or summer after it reaches full maturity.

children.label: waxy wheat
children.definition: A type of wheat in which the starch content of grains is high in amylopectin.

children.label: wheat classes
children.definition: Wheat classes are determined (1) by the hardness and color of their kernels and (2) by the time of year they are planted and harvested. These factors, along with their protein content and gluten strength, determine their milling and baking characteristics and whether the resulting wheat flours are better suited for making bread, pasta, cake or pastries. Each wheat class represents a separate market.

children.label: soft red winter wheat
children.definition: A wheat class seeded in the fall, has low to medium protein content, with a soft endosperm; and is used in making cakes, pastries, flat breads, and crackers. Grown in the eastern third of the U.S., east of the Mississippi River. It has a high yield, but relatively low protein.

children.label: hard red spring wheat
children.definition: The wheat class that contains the highest percentage of proteins, making it an excellent bread wheat, with superior milling and baking characteristics; chiefly grown in Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, and Minnesota; seeded in the spring, and may have a hard or soft endosperm.

children.label: soft white wheat
children.definition: A wheat class used much in the same way as Soft Red Winter (for bakery products other than bread). Grown mainly in the Pacific Northwest, and to a lesser extent in California, Michigan, Wisconsin, and New York, of low protein, but high yield. Produces flour for cakes, crackers, cookies, pastries, quick breads, muffins, snack foods.

children.label: hard red winter wheat
children.definition: The class of wheat used mostly for bread and all-purpose flour; seeded in the fall; ranges from medium to high in protein; may have either a hard or soft endosperm; accounts for more than 40% of the US wheat crop and more than half of US wheat exports; produced in the Great Plains. Wide range of protein, good milling and baking characteristics. Used to produce bread, rolls, and, to a lesser extent, sweet goods and all-purpose flour.

children.label: hard white wheat
children.definition: Newest white class of wheat to be grown in the U.S. Closely related to red wheats (except for color genes), this wheat has a milder, sweeter flavor, equal fiber, and similar milling and baking properties. Used in yeast breads, hard rolls, bulgur, tortillas, and oriental noodles. Used in domestic markets and exported in limited quantities.

children.label: durum wheat
children.definition: The hardest of all U.S. wheats, seeded in the spring, and contains a high amount of protein, which is good for pasta products (macaroni, spaghetti, and other noodles), grown in the same northern area as Hard Red Spring wheat--mainly in North Dakota.

children.label: middlings
children.definition: The coarse particles containing the wheat germ and the fine particles of wheat bran separated during milling. Valuable for feed, middlings contain a large proportion of protein and digestible nutrients.

children.label: sweetcorn
children.definition: Fresh kernels of a variety of corn (Zea mays) with a high sugar content and a low starch content, eaten as a vegetable.

children.label: masa
children.definition: A corn dough made by boiling corn in powdered lime, washing it, letting it dry, and then grinding the remaining mixture. Water is added to this ground meal to form dough that is used to make tortillas and tamales.

children.label: high fructose corn syrup
children.definition: Syrup made from corn used widely in foods and beverages as a cheaper alternative sweetener to sucrose (common table sugar). It is generated by enzymatic processing of natural corn syrup to produce a liquid most widely composed of 42 or 55% fructose, glucose, and various polysaccharides.

children.label: winter barley
children.definition: A general term for barley sown in the fall, persisting through the winter as seedlings, and harvested the following spring or summer after it reaches full maturity.

children.label: malt
children.definition: Product made by wetting grain (commonly barley) and allowing it to germinate long enough to produce adequate amounts of enzymes, and used especially in brewing and distilling.

children.label: grain foods
children.definition: Foods that are based completely or primarily on food grains.

children.label: rice wines
children.definition: An alcoholic beverage made from fermented rice.

children.label: glutinous rice
children.definition: Rice with 0-2% amylose or mainly amylopectin in the endosperm and pollen starch.

children.label: rough rice
children.definition: Unmilled rice that still contains the husk.

children.label: brown rice
children.definition: Rice from which only the hulls have been removed revealing the brown bran layers.

children.label: black rice
children.definition: An unmilled, medium grain rice with black bran.

children.label: red rice
children.definition: An unmilled, long-grain rice with red bran.

children.label: cocoa powder
children.definition: Ground cocoa solids.

children.label: chocolate liquor
children.definition: Chocolate liquor is the solid or semiplastic food prepared by finely grinding cocoa nibs. Chocolate liquor contains about half cocoa butter and half cocoa solids.

children.label: cocoa solids
children.definition: The nonfat component of cocoa beans.

children.label: cocoa nibs
children.definition: Cacao nibs are prepared by removing the shell from cured, cleaned, dried, and cracked cocoa beans.

children.label: chocolate
children.definition: A cocoa mixture usually including cocoa butter, cocoa liquor and a sweetener, most frequently used as a candy or flavoring. Includes bittersweet, semi-sweet chocolate. Cocoa content may vary.

children.label: milk chocolate
children.definition: A chocolate mixture usually including cocoa butter, cocoa liquor, a sweetener and milk or milk powder, most frequently used as a candy or flavoring.

children.label: white chocolate
children.definition: A mixture usually made of cocoa butter, milk or milk powder and a sweetner.

children.label: seed germ
children.definition: The embryo or the sprouting portion of the seed which is rich in fats and other nutrients and is separated from the endosperm during the milling process. Many seed germs are used as livestock feed or as a human nutritional supplement.

children.label: acai berries
children.definition: Small, round, purple fruits of the palm, Euterpe oleracea, harvested for fruit, pulp or juice.

children.label: atemoyas
children.definition: Interspecific cross between cherimoyas and sweetsops (Annona cherimola X Annona squamosa).

children.label: durians
children.definition: a large oval tasty but foul-smelling fruit with a prickly rind

children.label: tangors
children.definition: Fruits of the hybrid of the sweet orange (Citrus sinensis) and Mandarin orange (Citrus reticulata).

children.label: tangelos
children.definition: Fruit of the hybrid of the grapefruit (Citrus paradisi) and tangerine (Citrus reticulata).

children.label: verjuice
children.definition: The sour juice of unripe fruits, such as apples, crab apples or grapes, from which an acid liquor may also be made.

children.label: fruit wines
children.definition: Fruit wine is produced by the alcoholic fermentation of juice from ripe fruits and/or berries other than grapes. During production, pure condensed fruit must, fruit brandy, alcohol, and sugar may be added.

children.label: rose hips
children.definition: The fruit of the rose plant.

children.label: breadfruits
children.definition: An oval or round fruit with creamy white meat and a yellow-green rind with small rounded spines. It is usually boiled and eaten as a vegetable and resembles potato in flavor. It is a staple food in South Pacific and Malaysian cuisines.

children.label: pome fruits
children.definition: The fleshy, applelike fruit of a member of the apple family (Malaceae): an apple; also, though less exactly, a rose hip or haw or other smaller fruit of somewhat similar character of the rose family.

children.label: jackfruits
children.definition: Resembling breadfruits, jackfruits are much larger and can weigh up to 100 pounds. It is usually boiled, tastes like potato, and is eaten as a vegetable in South Pacific and Malaysian cuisines.

children.label: sago
children.definition: A powdered starch derived from sago palms (and other tropical palm species) and used in foods and as textile stiffening. Sago starch is similar to tapioca.

children.label: green beans
children.definition: The immature, green, succulent pods of Phaseolus vulgaris.

children.label: cowpeas
children.definition: any bean of the genus Vigna.

children.label: alfalfa
children.definition: A valuable leguminous crop for forage or hay used in livestock feeding.

children.label: high fructose corn syrup
children.definition: Syrup made from corn used widely in foods and beverages as a cheaper alternative sweetener to sucrose (common table sugar). It is generated by enzymatic processing of natural corn syrup to produce a liquid most widely composed of 42 or 55% fructose, glucose, and various polysaccharides.

children.label: white tea
children.definition: Tea made from the dried leaves and buds of the Camellia sinensis plant.

children.label: babassu oil
children.definition: The oil extracted from kernels (seeds) of the babassu palm, Attalea speciosa. The oil is used in food, cosmetics and soaps, having properties similar to coconut oil.

children.label: soy protein
children.definition: Proteins which are present in or isolated from soybeans.

children.label: natto
children.definition: A Japanese condiment and flavoring which has a glutinous texture and strong cheeselike flavor and is made of steamed, fermented and mashed soybeans.

children.label: okara
children.definition: Okara is a by-product of soydrink and tofu making process. It is rich in insoluble dietary fibre, proteins and fats.

children.label: douchi
children.definition: Chinese traditional fermented and salted black soybean food product that is rich in proteins.

children.label: miso
children.definition: A fermented soybean paste that may also contain rice, barley or wheat.

children.label: palm kernel oil
children.definition: The oil from the kernel or "nut" of the palm. Compare with palm oils.

children.label: oilmeals
children.definition: The product obtained by grinding the cakes, chips, or flakes that remain after most of the oil is removed from oilseeds. Oilseed meals are mainly used as a feedstuff for livestock and poultry. They are also used as a raw material in processing edible vegetable-protein products.

children.label: oilseed cakes
children.definition: The solid byproduct or residue obtained after extracting oil from oilseeds.

children.label: olive cake
children.definition: The solid byproduct or residue derived from olive pressing, that consists of pulp and pit of the olive fruit.

children.label: soapstock
children.definition: The fatty material from which soap is made; a byproduct of oilseed refining.

children.label: vegetables
children.definition: Any part of a plant that is commonly eaten by humans as food, but is not considered to be a culinary fruit, nut, herb, spice or grain.

children.label: green beans
children.definition: The immature, green, succulent pods of Phaseolus vulgaris.

children.label: mustard greens
children.definition: The young, dark green leaves of mustard plants that are used as a cooked vegetable or as a salad green. The leaves have a strong, peppery taste.

children.label: chard
children.definition: A green, leafy vegetable used for salads from the beet, Beta vulgaris subsp. vulgaris.

children.label: yams
children.definition: Yams in the U.S. are actually sweet potatoes. USDA requires that the label "yam" always be accompanied by "sweetpotato" for this reason. True yams are Dioscorea species.

children.label: sweetcorn
children.definition: Fresh kernels of a variety of corn (Zea mays) with a high sugar content and a low starch content, eaten as a vegetable.

children.label: winter squashes
children.definition: Any of various hard-shelled squashes that can be stored for several months.

children.label: cardoons
children.definition: A pale green vegetable that resembles celery and artichoke in flavor.

children.label: shallots
children.definition: A type of onion which is formed with a head made up of several cloves, resembling garlic.

children.label: microgreens
children.definition: Seedlings of vegetables or herbs harvested before true leaves appear. Microgreens have superior flavor and aroma and are larger than sprouts.

children.label: sprouts (food)
children.definition: The tender new shoots of germinated seeds (such as mung beans, soybeans, lentils, alfalfa and radish) that are eaten raw or cooked in stir-fry recipes.

children.label: bean sprouts
children.definition: The edible seedlings of bean plants, especially those of the mung bean.

children.label: hay
children.definition: Grasses, clover, alfalfa and other legumes, or any other leafy plant material that is cut and dried to be used for animal feeding.

children.label: paperboard
children.definition: The distinction between paper and paperboard is not sharp, but broadly speaking, the thicker (greater than 0.3 mm (0.012 in.), heavier, and more rigid grades of paper are called paperboard.

children.label: guaiac
children.definition: Resin from wood of certain species of Guaiacum. It is used as clinical reagent for occult blood.

children.label: topiary
children.definition: Plants that have been trimmed or clipped into decorative shapes.

children.label: seed cotton
children.definition: Unginned cotton which consists of the seed with the attached lint as picked from the boll.

children.label: lint cotton
children.definition: Cotton fibers that have been removed from the seed during the cotton ginning process.

children.label: wood fibers
children.definition: A wood cell comparatively long (less than or equal to 40 to 300 mm, less than or equal to 1.5 to 12 in.), narrow, tapering, and closed at both ends.

children.label: wood veneer
children.definition: A thin layer or sheet of wood.

children.label: wood flour
children.definition: Wood reduced to finely divided particles, approximately the same as those of cereal flours in size, appearance, and texture, and passing a 40 to 100 mesh screen.

children.label: wood-based panels
children.definition: A generic term for a material manufactured from wood veneer, strands, flakes, particles, or fibers or other lignocellulosic material and a synthetic resin or other binder.

children.label: particleboards
children.definition: Structural panel products made of wood fragments, such as chips or shavings, that are mechanically pressed into sheet form and bonded together with resin under heat and pressure.

children.label: waferboards
children.definition: A particle panel product made of wafer-type flakes. Usually manufactured to posses equal properties in all directions parallel to the plane of the panel.

children.label: flakeboards
children.definition: A generic term indicating a manufactured panel product composed of flakes bonded with a synthetic resin.

children.label: oriented strandboards
children.definition: An engineered structural wood-based panel composed of wood strands, flakes or wafers bonded under heat and pressure with a waterproof resin. The external layers are aligned in the panel direction and the inner layers are either cross-aligned or randomly-oriented. Common uses are sheathing in walls, floors, and roofs.

children.label: plywood
children.definition: A glued wood panel made up of relatively thin layers of veneer with the grain of adjacent layers at right angles or of veneer in combination with a core of lumber or of reconstituted wood. The usual constructions have an odd number of layers.

children.label: softwood plywood
children.definition: Structural material made of layers of softwood veneer glued together, under heat and pressure, with the grains of adjoining layers at right angles to each other.

children.label: fiberboards
children.definition: A generic term inclusive of panel products of various densities manufactured of refined or partially refined wood (or other lignocellulosic) fibers. Bonding agents may be added.

children.label: hardboard
children.definition: A generic term for a panel manufactured primarily from interfelted lignocellulosic fibers (usually wood), consolidated under heat and pressure in a hot press to a density of 496 kg m-3 (31 lb ft-3) or greater. May be manufactured using either a dry-process or wet-process.

children.label: medium density fiberboards
children.definition: An engineered wood product formed by breaking down softwood into wood fibres, compressing it with a binding material, such as glue, wax and resin, and forming panels by applying high temperature and pressure. These panels have a density of around 800 kg/m3.

children.label: wood beams
children.definition: A structural timber (i.e., wood which is relatively large in size, strength and stiffness) supporting a load applied transversely to it.

children.label: hardwood
children.definition: Generally one of the botanical groups of trees that have vessels or pores and broad leaves, in contrast to the conifers or softwoods. The term has no reference to the actual hardness of the wood.

children.label: pulpwood
children.definition: wood destined or suited for pulp manufacture, including standing or felled trees, logging residues, sawmill wastes, etc.

children.label: tropical wood
children.definition: Wood from a tropical or subtropical tree species.

children.label: refractory wood
children.definition: Wood that is difficult to dry, treat with preservatives or process using conventional methods.

children.label: roundwood
children.definition: solid wood that is in the round state. This term is also used for the volume of logs required to produce a given quantity of lumber, panels, pulp, paper or other wood products.

children.label: wood logs
children.definition: individual pieces of roundwood.

children.label: sawlogs
children.definition: A log large enough to be sawed economically into boards on a sawmill. Sawlogs are usually at least 8 inches in diameter at the small end.

children.label: cordwood
children.definition: Wood that is cut in short lengths, usually measured in cords and commonly used as fuel. Applies also to other products measured in cords.

children.label: recycled wood
children.definition: Any wood or wood fuel which is derived from such products or processes as pallets, skids, spools, packaging materials, bulky wood waste or scraps from newly built wood products, provided such wood is not treated wood.

children.label: softwood
children.definition: Generally, one of the botanical groups of trees that have no vessels and in most cases have needlelike or scalelike leaves, the conifers, also the wood produced by such trees. The term has no reference to the actual hardness of the wood.

children.label: lumber
children.definition: The product of the saw and planing mill for which manufacturing is limited to sawing, resawing, passing lengthwise through a standard planing machine, crosscutting to length, and matching. Lumber may be made from either softwood or hardwood

children.label: finger-jointed lumber
children.definition: An end joint made up of several meshing wedges or fingers of wood bonded together with an adhesive. Fingers are sloped and may be cut parallel to either the wide or narrow face of the piece.

children.label: finger-jointed lumber
children.definition: An end joint made up of several meshing wedges or fingers of wood bonded together with an adhesive. Fingers are sloped and may be cut parallel to either the wide or narrow face of the piece.

children.label: laminated veneer lumber
children.definition: An engineered wood product created by parallel lamination of veneers glued under heat and pressure with the grain of each veneer running parallel to the longitudinal axis of the billet.

children.label: wood trusses
children.definition: An assembly of members, such as beams, bars, rods, and the like, so combined as to form a rigid framework. All members are interconnected to form triangles.

children.label: glulam
children.definition: A manufactured structural timber product composed of layers of dimensional lumber glued together.

children.label: palm oils
children.definition: Oils pressed from the pulp of the fruit of various palms (Arecaceae). The African palm (Elaeis guineensis) is a common source for palm oil. Palm oils are high in saturated fat and carotene, and used in foods, soaps, cosmetics, candles. Compare with palm kernel oil.

children.label: virgin olive oil
children.definition: A grade of olive oil indicating oil processed without any chemical treatment and containing no additives.

children.label: lampante olive oil
children.definition: A nonedible oil derived from olive fruit and is used for industrial purposes.

children.label: babassu oil
children.definition: The oil extracted from kernels (seeds) of the babassu palm, Attalea speciosa. The oil is used in food, cosmetics and soaps, having properties similar to coconut oil.

children.label: palm kernel oil
children.definition: The oil from the kernel or "nut" of the palm. Compare with palm oils.

children.label: mango butter
children.definition: A natural fat extracted from kernels of the mango.

children.label: mango butter
children.definition: A natural fat extracted from kernels of the mango.

children.label: foie gras
children.definition: The liver of a goose or duck that is usually served as a spread.

children.label: lard
children.definition: Rendered fat derived from swine. Its composition, characteristics and consistency vary according to the feeding regime.

children.label: choice white grease
children.definition: A specific grade of mostly pork fat defined by hardness, color, fatty acid content, moisture, insolubles, unsaponifiables and free fatty acids.

children.label: milk fat
children.definition: Lipid component of animal milks.

children.label: anhydrous milk fat
children.definition: A dairy product made from cream or butter containing at least 99.8% milk fat and 0.10% moisture.

children.label: suet
children.definition: The hard white fat from around the kidneys and loins of animals that is used in cooking and for making tallow.

children.label: tallow
children.definition: The fat rendered from the adipose tissue of cattle and sheep used in candlemaking, soap manufacture, etc. Grades are based on hardness, moisture, insolubles, titer, clarity and free fatty acid content.

children.label: butter oil
children.definition: A dairy product made from cream or butter containing at least 99.5% milk fat and 0.20% moisture.

children.label: tripe
children.definition: A retail cut of beef, consisting of the walls of the rumen and the reticulum. Tripe can also come from pork and sheep.

children.label: sweetbreads
children.definition: The thymus glands of veal, young beef, lamb and pork used as food.

children.label: cultured meat
children.definition: Meat produced from the skeletal muscle or muscle cells or stem cells in laboratory conditions by using tissue engineering techniques.

children.label: boxed beef
children.definition: Cuts of beef sealed in vacuum packs to be shipped in cardbard boxes, often ready for retail sale.

children.label: mutton
children.definition: Meat from sheep that are over one year old.

children.label: pork bellies
children.definition: The source of bacon. The pork belly is the lower side of a hog remaining after the loin and spareribs have been removed.

children.label: butter oil
children.definition: A dairy product made from cream or butter containing at least 99.5% milk fat and 0.20% moisture.

children.label: raw milk
children.definition: Fresh, unprocessed milk as it comes from a cow, goat or other mammal.

children.label: ice milk
children.definition: Ice milk is similar to ice cream but it contains less milk fat (2-5 % vs. 10%) and milk solids(11-14%) and has a lighter, less creamy texture.

children.label: low fat milk
children.definition: Milk containing at least 8.25% solids and from which sufficient milk fat has been removed to produce a milk fat content of 0.5, 1.0, or 2.0%.

children.label: dried milk
children.definition: Dairy product made from milk by the removal of 95-98% of the water.

children.label: dried skim milk
children.definition: The product obtained by removing water from pasteurized skim milk. It contains not more than 5% moisture and not more than 1.5% milk fat unless otherwise indicated.

children.label: skim milk
children.definition: Milk from which sufficient cream has been removed to reduce its milk fat content to less than 0.5 % (usually less than 0.1%).

children.label: low fat milk
children.definition: Milk containing at least 8.25% solids and from which sufficient milk fat has been removed to produce a milk fat content of 0.5, 1.0, or 2.0%.

children.label: ice milk
children.definition: Ice milk is similar to ice cream but it contains less milk fat (2-5 % vs. 10%) and milk solids(11-14%) and has a lighter, less creamy texture.

children.label: reconstituted milk
children.definition: Reconstituted milk is the product obtained by the addition of potable water to dried milk.

children.label: sweetened condensed milk
children.definition: Made by the partial removal of water from fluid milk, with a suitable sweetener added in amounts sufficient to prevent spoilage.

children.label: whey
children.definition: The portion of milk remaining after the fat and casein (curd) have been removed. It contains about 93.5% water and 6.5% lactose, protein, minerals, enzymes, water-soluble vitamins and traces of fat.

children.label: cheese milk
children.definition: Milk that is suitable for cheesemaking.

children.label: processed cheeses
children.definition: Blends of several types of cheese mixed and melted together with added emulsifiers and preservatives, sometimes sold in individually wrapped thin slices.

children.label: quarg
children.definition: A soft, unripened, fresh cheese that is about the consistency of yogurt.

children.label: paneer
children.definition: A fresh soft white cheese, orginating from India, which is used in Indian, Afghan and Iranian cookery

children.label: sterilized milk
children.definition: Milk that has been heated to a temperature and for a time that kills all bacteria and spores, giving it an extended shelf life.

children.label: fluid milk
children.definition: Milk commonly marketed as fresh liquid milks and creams. It is the most perishable and highest-priced form of milk.

children.label: recombined milk
children.definition: Recombined milk is the product obtained from the blend of skimmed milk, milk fat and water.

children.label: ghee
children.definition: A type of clarified butter that has a nutty, caramel-like flavor and aroma.

children.label: concentrated milk
children.definition: Made by the partial removal of water from fluid milk, however, unlike evaporated milk it is not subjected to further heat treatment to prevent spoilage.

children.label: evaporated milk
children.definition: Dairy product made by removal of about 60% of the water to concentrate the milk and sterilizing to prevent spoilage.

children.label: fish sauce
children.definition: A pungent, salty seasoning or condiment in Southeast Asian cuisine that is made from fermented anchovies or other fish.

children.label: condiments
children.definition: Seasonings and flavorings that are generally added to foods by the consumer after preparation.

children.label: tripe
children.definition: A retail cut of beef, consisting of the walls of the rumen and the reticulum. Tripe can also come from pork and sheep.

children.label: sweetbreads
children.definition: The thymus glands of veal, young beef, lamb and pork used as food.

children.label: cultured meat
children.definition: Meat produced from the skeletal muscle or muscle cells or stem cells in laboratory conditions by using tissue engineering techniques.

children.label: boxed beef
children.definition: Cuts of beef sealed in vacuum packs to be shipped in cardbard boxes, often ready for retail sale.

children.label: mutton
children.definition: Meat from sheep that are over one year old.

children.label: pork bellies
children.definition: The source of bacon. The pork belly is the lower side of a hog remaining after the loin and spareribs have been removed.

children.label: novel foods
children.definition: Foods produced from ingredients that have not traditionally been used for human consumption in the area of the world in question, or that are produced by a new or extensively modified process.

children.label: low moisture foods
children.definition: Low moisture foods have low water activity and do not support the growth of spoilage or foodborne pathogens. These foods could be naturally low in water activity or that have been dried to lower the water activity.

children.label: natto
children.definition: A Japanese condiment and flavoring which has a glutinous texture and strong cheeselike flavor and is made of steamed, fermented and mashed soybeans.

children.label: douchi
children.definition: Chinese traditional fermented and salted black soybean food product that is rich in proteins.

children.label: miso
children.definition: A fermented soybean paste that may also contain rice, barley or wheat.

children.label: kimchi
children.definition: A Korean dish made of pungent, pickled cabbage.

children.label: fish sauce
children.definition: A pungent, salty seasoning or condiment in Southeast Asian cuisine that is made from fermented anchovies or other fish.

children.label: instant foods
children.definition: Foods in dried form that are ready to eat with the addition of water.

children.label: organic foods
children.definition: Organic food is produced without: antibiotics; growth hormones; most conventional pesticides; petroleum- based fertilizers or sewage sludge-based fertilizers; bioengineering; or ionizing radiation. USDA certification is required before a product can be labeled "organic". Companies, including restaurants, that handle or process organic food must be certified also.

children.label: grain foods
children.definition: Foods that are based completely or primarily on food grains.

children.label: fast foods
children.definition: Foods designed for ready availability, use, or consumption and sold at eating establishments for quick availability or take-out.

children.label: staple foods
children.definition: Foods that are basic to the diet/cuisine of the culture, like wheat flour, rice, corn, yams, sugar, salt, etc.

children.label: processed foods
children.definition: Foods that are manufactured, usually on a large scale, using any of a wide variety of processing techniques, most often with the goal of preserving food for market.

children.label: prepared foods
children.definition: Food products that have been manufactured, often with the intention of making food preparation and meal delivery easier for food industry and private consumers.

children.label: ready-to-cook foods
children.definition: Foods that are processed and/or prepared to be ready to cook with very little additional effort.

children.label: raw milk
children.definition: Fresh, unprocessed milk as it comes from a cow, goat or other mammal.

children.label: fresh produce
children.definition: Raw fruits and vegetables.

children.label: verjuice
children.definition: The sour juice of unripe fruits, such as apples, crab apples or grapes, from which an acid liquor may also be made.

children.label: porridge
children.definition: A porridge is a hot cereal that can be made from a variety of ground, chopped or crushed grains, vegetables, legumes etc., which are boiled in water or milk to make it as a mushy dish. It can be soft or thick and is mostly eaten as a breakfast.

children.label: crackers
children.definition: Baked crisp snack foods made from unleavened grain flour dough to which flavorings or seasonings may be added.

children.label: pound cakes
children.definition: A creamy, moist cake that is characterized with firm texture and creamy mouthfeel upon mastication. It contains equal portions of wheat flour, eggs, sugar and butter or margarine.

children.label: sponge cakes
children.definition: A light soft cake, usually made without added fat or shortening and leavened with eggs.

children.label: food groups
children.definition: A food group is defined as the grouping of food items that have similar caloric and nutrient qualities. According to the USDA, the five major food groups are grains, vegetables, fruits, dairy and meat and meat alternatives. A balanced diet should contain something from each of the five major food groups.

children.label: breadings
children.definition: Bread or cracker crumbs used to coat foods.

children.label: genetically modified foods
children.definition: Foods produced from genetically modified organisms. These species have undergone directed modification of their gene complement using such techniques as altering the DNA, substituting genetic material by means of a virus, transplanting whole nuclei, transplanting cell hybrids, etc.

children.label: cocoa powder
children.definition: Ground cocoa solids.

children.label: low acid foods
children.definition: Food with pH values higher than 4.6.

children.label: high fructose corn syrup
children.definition: Syrup made from corn used widely in foods and beverages as a cheaper alternative sweetener to sucrose (common table sugar). It is generated by enzymatic processing of natural corn syrup to produce a liquid most widely composed of 42 or 55% fructose, glucose, and various polysaccharides.

children.label: plant-based foods
children.definition: Foods originating from plant sources.

children.label: edible films
children.definition: Packaging materials that can be directly consumed. They provide barrier and protection, while enhancing quality and safety of food products.

children.label: imitation foods
children.definition: Products consisting of regular foods and/or chemical formulations that may be used in place of the foods they imitate. Often imitation foods are used by consumers for health or economic reasons.

children.label: milk substitutes
children.definition: Foods that are used to replace cow's milk in the human diet, made with nondairy ingredients.

children.label: surimi
children.definition: A processed seafood product that is typically made from Alaskan pollack that is flavored, precooked, and reformed into shapes that resemble shellfish. Imitation crabmeat is an example of surimi.

children.label: cured foods
children.definition: Food that has been treated with salt or nitrate or nitrite to preserve it. A very old method of food preservation.

children.label: seafoods
children.definition: Edible aquatic (freshwater or marine) organisms such as fish, shellfish, or seaweed that is used as food.

children.label: surimi
children.definition: A processed seafood product that is typically made from Alaskan pollack that is flavored, precooked, and reformed into shapes that resemble shellfish. Imitation crabmeat is an example of surimi.

children.label: mortadella
children.definition: A large, seasoned, smoked Italian sausage made of ground pork, beef, and pork fat.

children.label: chorizo
children.definition: A very spicy pork sausage seasoned with garlic and chili powder.

children.label: animal-based foods
children.definition: Foods originating from animal sources.

children.label: dough sponges
children.definition: An intermediate step in the dough making process, usually a fermented mixture of flour, yeast and liquids.

children.label: enriched foods
children.definition: Foods to which nutrients were added in order to replace losses of the nutrient that occured during processing.

children.label: perishable foods
children.definition: Foods that are subject to loss of quality, usually by destruction, decay or spoilage.

children.label: artificially sweetened beverages
children.definition: Beverages sweetened with sweetening agents that are synthetic or artificial as opposed to naturally-occurring. Examples of sweetening agents include aspartame, sucralose, and saccharin.

children.label: alcoholic beverages
children.definition: Drinkable liquids containing ethanol.

children.label: mash
children.definition: A crushed fermentable mixture, typically malt, grain meal or fruit, used to produce alcoholic beverages such as whiskey or beer.

children.label: beers
children.definition: A fermented, carbonated, alcoholic beverage containing one-half of 1 percent or more of alcohol by volume. Generally brewed from malt (mostly barley malt), hops (for flavoring) and water. Other cereals such as corn and rice may be used.

children.label: absinthe
children.definition: An extract of absinthium and other bitter herbs, containing 60% alcohol. Prolonged ingestion causes nervousness, convulsions, trismus, amblyopia, optic neuritis, and mental deterioration.

children.label: wines
children.definition: All alcoholic beverages made from the fermentation of grape juice, other fruits or vegetative parts. Wine may be sparkling or carbonated, made from condensed grape must, made from agricultural products other than the juice of grapes, and includes products sold as wine such as imitation wine, cider and sake.

children.label: dessert wines
children.definition: Wine having an alcoholic content in excess of 14 percent but not in excess of 24 percent by volume.

children.label: table wines
children.definition: Any wine containing less than 14 percent alcohol by volume, usually meant to be served with meals. Not to be confused with sweet wines, dessert wines, fortified wines, etc.

children.label: mead
children.definition: A fermented beverage made of honey, water and yeast.

children.label: fortified wines
children.definition: A wine to which additional alcohol has been added, often in the form of brandy.

children.label: fruit wines
children.definition: Fruit wine is produced by the alcoholic fermentation of juice from ripe fruits and/or berries other than grapes. During production, pure condensed fruit must, fruit brandy, alcohol, and sugar may be added.

children.label: sparkling wines
children.definition: Wine made effervescent with carbon dioxide resulting solely from the fermentation of the wine within a closed container, tank or bottle.

children.label: rice wines
children.definition: An alcoholic beverage made from fermented rice.

children.label: kombucha
children.definition: A fermented tea beverage obtained by the fermentation of sugared black or green tea with yeast, acetic acid bacteria and lactic acid bacteria.

children.label: beers
children.definition: A fermented, carbonated, alcoholic beverage containing one-half of 1 percent or more of alcohol by volume. Generally brewed from malt (mostly barley malt), hops (for flavoring) and water. Other cereals such as corn and rice may be used.

children.label: wines
children.definition: All alcoholic beverages made from the fermentation of grape juice, other fruits or vegetative parts. Wine may be sparkling or carbonated, made from condensed grape must, made from agricultural products other than the juice of grapes, and includes products sold as wine such as imitation wine, cider and sake.

children.label: dessert wines
children.definition: Wine having an alcoholic content in excess of 14 percent but not in excess of 24 percent by volume.

children.label: table wines
children.definition: Any wine containing less than 14 percent alcohol by volume, usually meant to be served with meals. Not to be confused with sweet wines, dessert wines, fortified wines, etc.

children.label: mead
children.definition: A fermented beverage made of honey, water and yeast.

children.label: fortified wines
children.definition: A wine to which additional alcohol has been added, often in the form of brandy.

children.label: fruit wines
children.definition: Fruit wine is produced by the alcoholic fermentation of juice from ripe fruits and/or berries other than grapes. During production, pure condensed fruit must, fruit brandy, alcohol, and sugar may be added.

children.label: sparkling wines
children.definition: Wine made effervescent with carbon dioxide resulting solely from the fermentation of the wine within a closed container, tank or bottle.

children.label: rice wines
children.definition: An alcoholic beverage made from fermented rice.

children.label: energy drinks
children.definition: A beverage that contains caffeine as an ingredient, along with other ingredients, such as taurine, herbal supplements, vitamins, and added sugars. It is usually marketed as a product that can improve perceived energy, stamina, athletic performance, or concentration.

children.label: kombucha
