children.definition: A fermented tea beverage obtained by the fermentation of sugared black or green tea with yeast, acetic acid bacteria and lactic acid bacteria.

children.label: spent coffee grounds
children.definition: The waste product that remain in a pot after brewing coffee.

children.label: sugar sweetened beverages
children.definition: Liquids that are sweetened with various forms of added sugars. These beverages include, but are not limited to, soda (regular, not sugar-free), fruitades, sports drinks, energy drinks, sweetened waters, and coffee and tea beverages with added sugars.

children.label: medical foods
children.definition: A food which is formulated to be consumed or administered enterally under the supervision of a physician and which is intended for the specific dietary management of a disease or condition for which distinctive nutritional requirements, based on recognized scientific principles, are established by medical evaluation.

children.label: fortified foods
children.definition: Foods which contain a higher nutrient content above natural levels because of the addition of nutrients during processing.

children.label: sweeteners
children.definition: Substances that sweeten food, beverages, medications, etc., such as sugar, saccharine or other low-calorie synthetic products.

children.label: nonnutritive sweeteners
children.definition: Sweeteners that do not have any significant energy or nutrient content

children.label: finger foods
children.definition: Finger food is food that is eaten directly with hands. It can be an entire meal or part of meal, for example: a piece of fruit or vegetable, cheese on sticks, a slice of bread, French fries, etc.

children.label: dried milk
children.definition: Dairy product made from milk by the removal of 95-98% of the water.

children.label: dried skim milk
children.definition: The product obtained by removing water from pasteurized skim milk. It contains not more than 5% moisture and not more than 1.5% milk fat unless otherwise indicated.

children.label: ice milk
children.definition: Ice milk is similar to ice cream but it contains less milk fat (2-5 % vs. 10%) and milk solids(11-14%) and has a lighter, less creamy texture.

children.label: functional foods
children.definition: Foods that are considered, by nature or manufacture, to contain significant levels of biologically active components which provide desirable health benefits beyond basic nutrition.

children.label: appetizers
children.definition: A small amount of food, generally eaten just before the main meal.

children.label: fish sauce
children.definition: A pungent, salty seasoning or condiment in Southeast Asian cuisine that is made from fermented anchovies or other fish.

children.label: reconstituted foods
children.definition: Foods which were concentrated or condensed and have been brought to their original strength by adding water.

children.label: bulk commodities
children.definition: Generally, high volume, low value unprocessed agricultural commodities, which are treated as though they are homogeneous (fungible) in nature prior to processing. Grains, oilseeds, and cotton are considered bulk commodities. Contrasting categories are high value commodities, semiprocessed and processed commodities, and consumer ready commodities.

children.label: bone meal
children.definition: Animal meal produced from bones that are steamed under pressure and then ground. It contains 1.5-2.5% nitrogen, 12-15% phosphorus, and 20-34% calcium.

children.label: oilmeals
children.definition: The product obtained by grinding the cakes, chips, or flakes that remain after most of the oil is removed from oilseeds. Oilseed meals are mainly used as a feedstuff for livestock and poultry. They are also used as a raw material in processing edible vegetable-protein products.

children.label: oilseed cakes
children.definition: The solid byproduct or residue obtained after extracting oil from oilseeds.

children.label: olive cake
children.definition: The solid byproduct or residue derived from olive pressing, that consists of pulp and pit of the olive fruit.

children.label: blood meal
children.definition: Meal produced from fresh animal blood which is high in lysine content (about 9% of the crude protein.)

children.label: feather meal
children.definition: Protein feed supplement obtained by hydrolysis of feathers under heat and pressure.

children.label: meat and bone meal
children.definition: The protein residue left after the moisture and fat have been extracted in the normal rendering process. It includes bone, but excludes extraneous material such as hair, hoof or horn.

children.label: propolis
children.definition: A resinous substance obtained from beehives that is used traditionally as an antimicrobial. It is a heterogeneous mixture of many substances.

children.label: honeydew honey
children.definition: Honey made by honeybees from the honeydew (sugary excretions of sap-sucking insects or aphids) or secretions of living parts of plants.

children.label: bee pollen
children.definition: Bee pollen is the pollen that bees collect from flowers and mix with nectar, honey and bee secretions which is stored in the comb and is fed to growing bee larvae.

children.label: rayon
children.definition: A manufactured, semi-synthetic fiber composed of regenerated cellulose which is produced from naturally-occurring polymers. It is used in fabrics for its high luster, silk-like quality.

children.label: seed cotton
children.definition: Unginned cotton which consists of the seed with the attached lint as picked from the boll.

children.label: lint cotton
children.definition: Cotton fibers that have been removed from the seed during the cotton ginning process.

children.label: wood fibers
children.definition: A wood cell comparatively long (less than or equal to 40 to 300 mm, less than or equal to 1.5 to 12 in.), narrow, tapering, and closed at both ends.

children.label: paperboard
children.definition: The distinction between paper and paperboard is not sharp, but broadly speaking, the thicker (greater than 0.3 mm (0.012 in.), heavier, and more rigid grades of paper are called paperboard.

children.label: guaiac
children.definition: Resin from wood of certain species of Guaiacum. It is used as clinical reagent for occult blood.

children.label: topiary
children.definition: Plants that have been trimmed or clipped into decorative shapes.

children.label: seed cotton
children.definition: Unginned cotton which consists of the seed with the attached lint as picked from the boll.

children.label: lint cotton
children.definition: Cotton fibers that have been removed from the seed during the cotton ginning process.

children.label: wood fibers
children.definition: A wood cell comparatively long (less than or equal to 40 to 300 mm, less than or equal to 1.5 to 12 in.), narrow, tapering, and closed at both ends.

children.label: wood veneer
children.definition: A thin layer or sheet of wood.

children.label: wood flour
children.definition: Wood reduced to finely divided particles, approximately the same as those of cereal flours in size, appearance, and texture, and passing a 40 to 100 mesh screen.

children.label: wood-based panels
children.definition: A generic term for a material manufactured from wood veneer, strands, flakes, particles, or fibers or other lignocellulosic material and a synthetic resin or other binder.

children.label: particleboards
children.definition: Structural panel products made of wood fragments, such as chips or shavings, that are mechanically pressed into sheet form and bonded together with resin under heat and pressure.

children.label: waferboards
children.definition: A particle panel product made of wafer-type flakes. Usually manufactured to posses equal properties in all directions parallel to the plane of the panel.

children.label: flakeboards
children.definition: A generic term indicating a manufactured panel product composed of flakes bonded with a synthetic resin.

children.label: oriented strandboards
children.definition: An engineered structural wood-based panel composed of wood strands, flakes or wafers bonded under heat and pressure with a waterproof resin. The external layers are aligned in the panel direction and the inner layers are either cross-aligned or randomly-oriented. Common uses are sheathing in walls, floors, and roofs.

children.label: plywood
children.definition: A glued wood panel made up of relatively thin layers of veneer with the grain of adjacent layers at right angles or of veneer in combination with a core of lumber or of reconstituted wood. The usual constructions have an odd number of layers.

children.label: softwood plywood
children.definition: Structural material made of layers of softwood veneer glued together, under heat and pressure, with the grains of adjoining layers at right angles to each other.

children.label: fiberboards
children.definition: A generic term inclusive of panel products of various densities manufactured of refined or partially refined wood (or other lignocellulosic) fibers. Bonding agents may be added.

children.label: hardboard
children.definition: A generic term for a panel manufactured primarily from interfelted lignocellulosic fibers (usually wood), consolidated under heat and pressure in a hot press to a density of 496 kg m-3 (31 lb ft-3) or greater. May be manufactured using either a dry-process or wet-process.

children.label: medium density fiberboards
children.definition: An engineered wood product formed by breaking down softwood into wood fibres, compressing it with a binding material, such as glue, wax and resin, and forming panels by applying high temperature and pressure. These panels have a density of around 800 kg/m3.

children.label: wood beams
children.definition: A structural timber (i.e., wood which is relatively large in size, strength and stiffness) supporting a load applied transversely to it.

children.label: hardwood
children.definition: Generally one of the botanical groups of trees that have vessels or pores and broad leaves, in contrast to the conifers or softwoods. The term has no reference to the actual hardness of the wood.

children.label: pulpwood
children.definition: wood destined or suited for pulp manufacture, including standing or felled trees, logging residues, sawmill wastes, etc.

children.label: tropical wood
children.definition: Wood from a tropical or subtropical tree species.

children.label: refractory wood
children.definition: Wood that is difficult to dry, treat with preservatives or process using conventional methods.

children.label: roundwood
children.definition: solid wood that is in the round state. This term is also used for the volume of logs required to produce a given quantity of lumber, panels, pulp, paper or other wood products.

children.label: wood logs
children.definition: individual pieces of roundwood.

children.label: sawlogs
children.definition: A log large enough to be sawed economically into boards on a sawmill. Sawlogs are usually at least 8 inches in diameter at the small end.

children.label: cordwood
children.definition: Wood that is cut in short lengths, usually measured in cords and commonly used as fuel. Applies also to other products measured in cords.

children.label: recycled wood
children.definition: Any wood or wood fuel which is derived from such products or processes as pallets, skids, spools, packaging materials, bulky wood waste or scraps from newly built wood products, provided such wood is not treated wood.

children.label: softwood
children.definition: Generally, one of the botanical groups of trees that have no vessels and in most cases have needlelike or scalelike leaves, the conifers, also the wood produced by such trees. The term has no reference to the actual hardness of the wood.

children.label: lumber
children.definition: The product of the saw and planing mill for which manufacturing is limited to sawing, resawing, passing lengthwise through a standard planing machine, crosscutting to length, and matching. Lumber may be made from either softwood or hardwood

children.label: finger-jointed lumber
children.definition: An end joint made up of several meshing wedges or fingers of wood bonded together with an adhesive. Fingers are sloped and may be cut parallel to either the wide or narrow face of the piece.

children.label: finger-jointed lumber
children.definition: An end joint made up of several meshing wedges or fingers of wood bonded together with an adhesive. Fingers are sloped and may be cut parallel to either the wide or narrow face of the piece.

children.label: laminated veneer lumber
children.definition: An engineered wood product created by parallel lamination of veneers glued under heat and pressure with the grain of each veneer running parallel to the longitudinal axis of the billet.

children.label: wood trusses
children.definition: An assembly of members, such as beams, bars, rods, and the like, so combined as to form a rigid framework. All members are interconnected to form triangles.

children.label: glulam
children.definition: A manufactured structural timber product composed of layers of dimensional lumber glued together.

children.label: palm oils
children.definition: Oils pressed from the pulp of the fruit of various palms (Arecaceae). The African palm (Elaeis guineensis) is a common source for palm oil. Palm oils are high in saturated fat and carotene, and used in foods, soaps, cosmetics, candles. Compare with palm kernel oil.

children.label: virgin olive oil
children.definition: A grade of olive oil indicating oil processed without any chemical treatment and containing no additives.

children.label: lampante olive oil
children.definition: A nonedible oil derived from olive fruit and is used for industrial purposes.

children.label: babassu oil
children.definition: The oil extracted from kernels (seeds) of the babassu palm, Attalea speciosa. The oil is used in food, cosmetics and soaps, having properties similar to coconut oil.

children.label: palm kernel oil
children.definition: The oil from the kernel or "nut" of the palm. Compare with palm oils.

children.label: mango butter
children.definition: A natural fat extracted from kernels of the mango.

children.label: mango butter
children.definition: A natural fat extracted from kernels of the mango.

children.label: mineral oil
children.definition: An oil derived from a mineral source (petroleum) as contrasted to oils derived from plants or animals.

children.label: lard
children.definition: Rendered fat derived from swine. Its composition, characteristics and consistency vary according to the feeding regime.

children.label: choice white grease
children.definition: A specific grade of mostly pork fat defined by hardness, color, fatty acid content, moisture, insolubles, unsaponifiables and free fatty acids.

children.label: milk fat
children.definition: Lipid component of animal milks.

children.label: anhydrous milk fat
children.definition: A dairy product made from cream or butter containing at least 99.8% milk fat and 0.10% moisture.

children.label: suet
children.definition: The hard white fat from around the kidneys and loins of animals that is used in cooking and for making tallow.

children.label: tallow
children.definition: The fat rendered from the adipose tissue of cattle and sheep used in candlemaking, soap manufacture, etc. Grades are based on hardness, moisture, insolubles, titer, clarity and free fatty acid content.

children.label: butter oil
children.definition: A dairy product made from cream or butter containing at least 99.5% milk fat and 0.20% moisture.

children.label: neutral oil
children.definition: An oil obtained by distillation, which is untreated with either acid or alkali.

children.label: resins
children.definition: Solid, semisolid, or pseudosolid resinâ€”An organic material that has an indefinite and often high molecular weight, exhibits a tendency to flow when subjected to stress, usually has a softening or melting range, and usually fractures conchoidally. (2) Liquid resinâ€”an organic polymeric liquid that, when converted to its final state for use, becomes a resin.

children.label: alkyd resins
children.definition: Synthetic polyester resins which are used in paints, adhesives and varnishes.

children.label: copal resin
children.definition: An immature, lustrous, subfossilized diterpenoid resin that is not polymerized or old enough to become amber.

children.label: guaiac
children.definition: Resin from wood of certain species of Guaiacum. It is used as clinical reagent for occult blood.

children.label: oleoresins
children.definition: A solution of resin in an essential oil that occurs in or exudes from many plants, especially softwoods. The oleoresin from pine is a solution of pine resin (rosin) in turpentine.

children.label: coproducts
children.definition: Any two or more products produced together from the same processing or manufacturing unit.

children.label: rayon
children.definition: A manufactured, semi-synthetic fiber composed of regenerated cellulose which is produced from naturally-occurring polymers. It is used in fabrics for its high luster, silk-like quality.

children.label: rockwool
children.definition: An inert, porous mineral product made from a mixture of rocks (diabase, limestone, coke, etc.) that is melted and spun into mineral wool fibres.

children.label: slag wool
children.definition: A porous, grayish-yellow mineral wool that is obtained by melting and spinning the slags or fused agglomerate by-products typically removed from blast furnaces.

children.label: synthetic rubber
children.definition: A manmade elastomer manufactured by polymerization of petroleum-derived products or other hydrocarbons, as compared with natural rubber obtained from trees.

children.label: taint
children.definition: An unwanted flavor or odor in fresh or processed food. The taint may come from degradation of the food or from contamination from another source.

children.label: umami
children.definition: A primary element of taste, accompanying yet independent of sweet, sour, salty, and bitter. Umami is the Japanese word for 'delicious' or 'savory' but is regarded as broth-like or meaty tasting in Western cultures. This taste detects the presence of glutamate.

children.label: product authenticity
children.definition: The degree to which a product meets the standards for quality, composition and manufacture.

children.label: food quality
children.definition: Ratings of the characteristics of food including flavor, appearance, nutritional content, and the amount of microbial and chemical contamination.

children.label: food spoilage
children.definition: Varying degrees of physical, chemical and/or biological deterioration of food sensory properties, nutrient content, and/or safety. Major causes include: 1) growth and activity of microorganisms, 2) natural enzymes, 3) insects, parasites and rodents, 4) temperature, 5) moisture and dryness, 6) air/oxygen, 7) light, 9) time.

children.label: defect action levels
children.definition: Levels of natural or unavoidable defects in foods that present no health hazards for humans.

children.label: food surfaces
children.definition: The surface of any food or food product.

children.label: falling number
children.definition: A method for the determination of the effect of alpha amylase activity during the baking process.

children.label: food matrix
children.definition: The nutrient and non-nutrient components of foods and their molecular relationships, i.e. chemical bonds, to each other.

children.label: nutritive value
children.definition: An indication of the contribution of a food to the nutrient content of the diet. This value depends on the quantity of a food which is digested and absorbed and the amounts of the essential nutrients (protein, fat, carbohydrate, minerals, vitamins) which it contains. This value can be affected by soil and growing conditions, handling and storage, and processing.

children.label: biofortification
children.definition: An increase in the nutritional value of plant foods obtained through convential crop breeding methods or through crop genetic engineering techniques. This contrasts with postharvest fortification in which nutrients are added during processing.

children.label: protein efficiency ratio
children.definition: An assessment of dietary protein quality by calculating weight gain divided by intake of a specific protein during a given period.

children.label: metabolizable energy
children.definition: The net energy in food or feed that is available to humans or animals by digestion and absorption, and measured as the difference between gross energy content and the energy lost as being undigested or indigestible.

children.label: digestible dry matter
children.definition: Amount of digestible fibre in a feed or forage.

children.label: digestible organic matter
children.definition: A percentage of energy and protein in forages/feed expressed as organic matter (DOM) intake minus fecal dry matter divided by dry matter intake times 100.

children.label: glycemic index
children.definition: A scale of the effects of foods on blood glucose concentrations shortly after ingestion.

children.label: glycemic load
children.definition: A quantitative value of a measured amount of a specific food that is equal to the glycemic index of that food multiplied by the carbohydrate content of that food.

children.label: digestible energy
children.definition: Energy in food or feed that is available to humans or animals by digestion, and measured as the difference between gross energy content and the energy lost in feces.

children.label: alkali spreading value
children.definition: A test for estimating the gelatinization temperature of starch utilizing a seven point scale of the degree of spreading of milled rice grains in potassium hydroxide solution.

children.label: drip loss
children.definition: The loss in weight of food products owing to extruding and dripping away of tissue juices, such as meat juices lost during the thawing of frozen meat.

children.label: marbling
children.definition: The presence of thin strips or flecks of fat within a meat cut. More marbling is usually associated with greater palatability.

children.label: deterioration
children.definition: The process by which products, materials, etc. fall from a higher to a lower level in quality.

children.label: value-added products
children.definition: Products that generally have increased in value due to processing.

children.label: biobased products
children.definition: Biobased products are fuels, chemicals, materials, or electric power or heat produced from biomass. Including any energy, commercial or industrial product (other than food or feed) that utilizes biological products or renewable domestic agricultural (plant, animal, and marine) or forestry materials.

children.label: biocomposites
children.definition: Manufactured products comprising at least one material derived from living organisms, such as natural fibers.

children.label: biofuels
children.definition: Gas or liquid fuel made from plant material (biomass). Includes wood, wood waste, wood liquors, peat, railroad ties, wood sludge, spent sulfite liquors, agricultural waste, straw, tires, fish oils, tall oil, sludge waste, waste alcohol, municipal solid waste, landfill gases, other waste, and ethanol blended into motor gasoline.

children.label: biodiesel
children.definition: A biofuel for use in diesel engines produced through the transesterfication of organically-derived oils or fats combined with alcohol (ethanol or methanol) in the presence of a catalyst. It may be used either as a replacement for or as a component of diesel fuel.

children.label: biogas
children.definition: Gas resulting from the decomposition of organic matter under anaerobic conditions. The principal constituents are methane and carbon dioxide.

children.label: biocoal
children.definition: A biomass fuel processed by torrefaction of agricultural wastes such as wood residues into a high density, energy-concentrated fuel product in the form of pellets or briquettes.

children.label: bioethanol
children.definition: An alcohol fuel made by fermentation of carbohydrates in sugar- or starch-rich crops such as corn or sugarcane, or other biomass sources including grasses.

children.label: adulterated products
children.definition: Products containing any deleterious substance rendering it injurious to health or products produced using ingredients or processes that are inconsistent with their labels. See Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act Section 402 [21 U.S.C. 342].

children.label: byproducts
children.definition: Products, including chemical substances, made during the manufacture, processing, or synthesis of something else.

children.label: chaff
children.definition: Seed coverings separated from cereal grains after threshing, together with other stem or leaf debris from the process.

children.label: animal byproducts
children.definition: Parts of carcasses of livestock or poultry, processed by cooking, curing, drying or other methods.

children.label: inedible offal
children.definition: Animal byproducts primarily from meat and poultry plants, including blood, bone, feathers and viscera.

children.label: blood meal
children.definition: Meal produced from fresh animal blood which is high in lysine content (about 9% of the crude protein.)

children.label: bone meal
children.definition: Animal meal produced from bones that are steamed under pressure and then ground. It contains 1.5-2.5% nitrogen, 12-15% phosphorus, and 20-34% calcium.

children.label: meat and bone meal
children.definition: The protein residue left after the moisture and fat have been extracted in the normal rendering process. It includes bone, but excludes extraneous material such as hair, hoof or horn.

children.label: feather meal
children.definition: Protein feed supplement obtained by hydrolysis of feathers under heat and pressure.

children.label: filter cake
children.definition: The solid or semisolid residue deposited on a filter following filtration of a fluid.

children.label: yellow grease
children.definition: A byproduct usually made up of restaurant greases (fats and oils from cooking). Another source is from rendering plants producing lower quality tallow.

children.label: spent coffee grounds
children.definition: The waste product that remain in a pot after brewing coffee.

children.label: coal tar
children.definition: A by-product of the destructive distillation of coal used as a topical antieczematic. It is an antipruritic and keratoplastic agent used also in the treatment of psoriasis and other skin conditions. Occupational exposure to soots, tars, and certain mineral oils is known to be carcinogenic according to the Fourth Annual Report on Carcinogens.

children.label: biosolids
children.definition: The organic solids product of wastewater treatment that can be beneficially utilized.

children.label: dried biosolids
children.definition: biosolids that contain >50% solids.

children.label: liquid biosolids
children.definition: Biosolids that contain 1-12% solids.

children.label: dewatered biosolids
children.definition: biosolids that contain 12-45% solids.

children.label: protein products
children.definition: For discussions of the naturally-occurring protein component(s) of plants or animals, which may have undergone processing, such as protein isolates.

children.label: protein hydrolysates
children.definition: A solution of amino acids and peptides prepared from protein by acid, alkali or enzymatic hydrolysis.

children.label: pea protein
children.definition: Dietary proteins that are present in or isolated from the seeds of Pisum sativum.

children.label: soy protein
children.definition: Proteins which are present in or isolated from soybeans.

children.label: Antiquities Act
children.definition: The Antiquities Act of 1906 provides for the protection of historic or prehistoric remains, or any object of antiquity, on Federal lands; establishes criminal sanctions for unauthorized destruction or appropriation of antiquities and authorizes scientific investigation of antiquities on Federal lands, subject to permit and regulations.

children.label: animal welfare
children.definition: The protection of animals in laboratories or other specific environments by promoting their health through nutrition, housing, care, climate, mental stimulation, and freedom from pain and suffering, disease, and disability.

children.label: thermal stress
children.definition: Stress due to extreme cold, hot, or unfavorable temperature on the physiological function of cells, tissues or an organism.

children.label: animal control services
children.definition: The provision of services in a municipality by authorized personnel to enforce animal control laws that support public safety and ensure the welfare of wild and domestic animals, including activities such as investigating animal cruelty incidents, licensing of animals, impounding stray animals, and controlling nuisance animals.

children.label: morbidity
children.definition: State of being ill or diseased. Morbidity is the occurrence of a disease or condition that alters health and quality of life.

children.label: basic reproduction number
children.definition: The expected number of new cases of an infection caused by an infected individual, in a population consisting of susceptible contacts only.

children.label: mortality
children.definition: All deaths reported in a given population.

children.label: winterkill
children.definition: The death of all or a part of a population due to exposure to cold temperatures or inclement weather conditions during winter.

children.label: fish kills
children.definition: The sudden death of fish due to natural causes, pollutants, or environmental factors such as the reduction of the dissolved oxygen concentration in a body of water.

children.label: animal law
children.definition: Laws and legislation that govern the treatment, confinement, or production of animals and livestock.

children.label: ownership
children.definition: The exclusive right to occupy, sell, bequeath or mortgage property.

children.label: public ownership
children.definition: Property that is exclusively controlled by a governing entity, whereby the governing entity has the right to sell, mortgage, occupy that property.

children.label: civil rights
children.definition: Rights of all individuals to equality under the law, sometimes denied because of personal characteristics (e.g., race, sex, ethnic background).

children.label: intellectual property rights
children.definition: The legal protection for inventions, including new technologies or new organisms (such as new plant varieties). The owner of these rights can control their use and earn the rewards for their use. This encourages further innovation and creativity for the benefit of us all. Intellectual property rights protection includes various types of patents, trademarks, and copyrights.

children.label: property rights
children.definition: The sum total of the rights pertaining to property ownership. In the case of real property it embraces the right to quiet enjoyment, the right to sell, to mortgage, to lease, to bequeath, to regain possession at the end of a lease, to build and remove improvements, and to control the property's use within the law. In short, it describes the scope of legal protections granted to property ownership.

children.label: trade agreements
children.definition: A negotiated agreement usually among two or more countries or regions to limit or alter their policies with respect to trade.

children.label: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
children.definition: A post- World War II international treaty for the regulation of trade policy and the reduction of tariffs and trade barriers which was subsumed into the World Trade Organization in 1995.

children.label: free trade
children.definition: A policy in international markets allowing unrestricted exchange of goods between countries without the imposition of special taxes and government interference.

children.label: food labeling
children.definition: Use of written, printed, or graphic materials upon or accompanying a food or its container or wrapper. The concept includes ingredients, nutritional value, directions, warnings, and other relevant information.

children.label: protected designation of origin
children.definition: Geographical indications on foods and other agricultural products, based upon European Union regulations, ensuring that only products originating in a given region are commercially identifiable as such.

children.label: ecolabeling
children.definition: A symbol, graphic or statement that appears on products or their packaging in order to convey an environmental aspect of that product to the consumer.

children.label: percentage ingredient labeling
children.definition: Quantitative declarations of ingredients that appear on products.

children.label: seal of quality
children.definition: Labels on products that reflect participation in a voluntary inspection and labeling program that esablishes quality standards for products from a specific industry and/or locality.

children.label: National Ambient Air Quality Standards
children.definition: Standards which define the levels of air quality which the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency judges are necessary to provide an adequate margin of safety to protect the public health.

children.label: water quality standards
children.definition: State-adopted and EPA-approved ambient standards for water bodies. The standards cover the use of the water body and the water quality criteria which must be met to protect the designated use or uses.

children.label: lumber grades
children.definition: The designation of the quality of a manufactured piece of wood or of logs.

children.label: Codex Alimentarius
children.definition: An international food standards code developed jointly by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the World Health Organization (WH0) in 1962.

children.label: safety standards
children.definition: Criteria for ensuring the safety of activities, processes, or products,.

children.label: water quality criteria
children.definition: Specific levels of water quality which, if reached, are expected to render a body of water suitable for its designated use. The criteria are based on specific levels of pollutants that would make the water harmful if used for drinking, swimming, farming, fish production, or industrial processes.

children.label: standards of identity
children.definition: Standards of identity define what a given food product is, its name, and the ingredients that must be used or may be used in the manufacture of the food.

children.label: National Environmental Policy Act
children.definition: An act to declare a National policy which will encourage productive and enjoyable harmony between man and his environment, to promote efforts which will prevent or eliminate damage to the environment and biosphere and stimulate the health and welfare of man, to enrich the understanding of the ecological systems and natural resources important to the Nation and to establish a Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ).

children.label: code of practice
children.definition: The rules and documented procedures established by regulatory bodies or trade associations which serve as a guide to acceptable practices. They do not have the force of law.

children.label: government deregulation
children.definition: The removal, reduction or relaxation of government regulations and restrictions on a previously regulated industry or market sector.

children.label: program eligibility
children.definition: Requirements that a person or group must meet in order to receive goods or services.

children.label: 4-H Youth Development Program
children.definition: The 4-H Youth Development Program is an international youth outreach organization founded in 1902 to foster agricultural, homemaking, leadership and other skills in young people. The 4-H name represents the ideals of the program with its focus on Head, Heart, Hands and Health. The program is administered by the United States Department of Agriculture Cooperative Extension Service.

children.label: disaster assistance
children.definition: Federal payments made to farmers because of a natural disaster when (1) planting is prevented or (2) crop yields are abnormally low because of adverse weather and related conditions. Disaster payments may be provided under existing legislation or under special legislation enacted after an extensive natural disaster.

children.label: politics
children.definition: Activities concerned with governmental policies, functions, etc.

children.label: United States Army Corps of Engineers
U.S. Cooperative Extension Service
children.definition: A national, publicly funded, nonformal education network that links the educational and research resources and activities of USDA with land grant universities in every State, territory, and the District of Columbia. The Federal partner is the Cooperative State Research, Education, and Extension Service. This unique Federal, State, and local partnership focuses on practical solutions to critical issues affecting people's daily lives.

children.label: Interagency Coordinating Committee on the Validation of Alternative Methods
United States Agency for International Development
Interagency Risk Assessment Consortium
children.definition: An association of representatives from federal agencies, institutes and centers who collectively work to further research, coordination, and communication in the area of food safety risk assessment.

children.label: Department of Health and Human Services
National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences
children.definition: The National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS) Superfund Basic Research Program, provides funding to 18 programs at 70 universities and institutions around the United States to study the human health effects of hazardous substances in the environment, especially those found at uncontrolled, leaking waste disposal sites.

children.label: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Farm Credit Administration
children.definition: As an independent agency in the Executive Branch of the U.S. Government, it is responsible for the regulation and examination of the Farm Credit System.

children.label: National Institute of Food and Agriculture
children.definition: An agency within U.S. Department of Agriculture formerly known as the Cooperative State Research, Education, and Extension Service, and renamed to the National Institute of Food and Agriculture on September 30, 2009.

children.label: Nutrition Evidence Systematic Review
children.definition: USDA's Nutrition Evidence Systematic Review (NESR), formerly the Nutrition Evidence Library (NEL), specializes in conducting food- and nutrition-related systematic reviews. NESR systematic reviews are research projects that answer important public health questions by using rigorous and transparent methods to search for, evaluate, analyze, and synthesize the body of scientific evidence on topics relevant to Federal policy and programs.

children.label: USDA National Agricultural Library
children.definition: One of five national libraries of the United States, housing one of the world's largest agricultural information collections which covers all aspects of agriculture and related sciences.

children.label: Long-Term Agroecosystem Research Network
children.definition: It is a partnership among 18 premier long-term research sites across the United States. LTAR was established to build the knowledge required for sustainable intensification of agriculture, increasing yields from the current agricultural land base while minimizing or reversing agricultureâ€™s adverse environmental impacts. Network research is organized around topics of sustainability of regional or national consequence, relying upon long-term databases, cross-site experiments, and computational modeling to tie experimental and monitoring conclusions from diverse locations to a broader vision of agriculture for the United States.

children.label: USDA National Plant Germplasm System
children.definition: The U.S. National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS) is collaborative effort to safeguard the genetic diversity of agriculturally important plants. The NPGS is managed by the Agricultural Research Service (ARS), the in-house research agency of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA).

children.label: Center for Nutrition Policy and Promotion
Farm Service Agency
children.definition: Stabilizing farm income, helping farmers conserve land and water resources, providing credit to new or disadvantaged farmers and ranchers, and helping farm operations recover from the effects of disaster are the missions of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency (FSA).

children.label: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
Grain Inspection Packers and Stockyards Administration
issues and policy
children.definition: A definite course or method of action selected by a governmental agency, institution, group or individual from among alternatives and, in the light of given conditions, to guide and usually determine present and future decisions. A specified decision or set of decisions designed to carry out such a chosen course of action.

children.label: environmental policy
children.definition: Official statements of principles, intentions, values, and objective which are based on legislation and the governing authority of a state and which serve as a guide for the operations of governmental and private activities in environmental affairs.

children.label: zero emissions
children.definition: Pollution abatement objective in which industrial processes or energy source emissions contribute no waste products, such as greenhouse gases, that pollute the environment or effect climate change; actual emissions may be offset through recycling, carbon sequestration or environmental credit trading.

children.label: food justice
children.definition: A movement for ensuring that all individuals have access to healthy, low cost, good quality, locally grown, culturally relevant and nutritious food.

children.label: food sovereignty
children.definition: The right of farmers, communities, countries to define their own food and agricultural policies or systems.

children.label: parity (economics)
children.definition: A level for agricultural commodity prices maintained by governmental support and intended to give farmers the same purchasing power they had during a selected base period.

children.label: reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation
children.definition: REDD+ stands for countries efforts to reduce emissions from deforestation and forest degradation, and foster conservation, sustainable management of forests, and enhancement of forest carbon stocks.

children.label: import quotas
children.definition: A quantitative limit placed on the importation of specific commodities.

children.label: market access
children.definition: The extent to which a good or a service can compete with locally-made products in another market.

children.label: trade agreements
children.definition: A negotiated agreement usually among two or more countries or regions to limit or alter their policies with respect to trade.

children.label: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
children.definition: A post- World War II international treaty for the regulation of trade policy and the reduction of tariffs and trade barriers which was subsumed into the World Trade Organization in 1995.

children.label: free trade
children.definition: A policy in international markets allowing unrestricted exchange of goods between countries without the imposition of special taxes and government interference.

children.label: export subsidies
children.definition: A direct or indirect compensation provided by governments to private commercial firms to promote exports of domestic products.

children.label: public policy
children.definition: A course or method of action selected, usually by a government, from among alternatives to guide and determine present and future decisions.

children.label: enterostomy
children.definition: Creation of an artificial external opening or fistula in the intestines.

children.label: surgical ablation
children.definition: Removal of tissue by vaporization, abrasion, or destruction. Methods used include heating tissue by hot liquids or microwave thermal heating, freezing (cryoablation), chemical ablation, and photoablation with lasers.

children.label: cryosurgery
children.definition: The use of freezing as a special surgical technique to destroy or excise tissue.

children.label: surgical transplantation
children.definition: Transference of a tissue or organ, alive or dead, within an individual, between individuals of the same species, or between individuals of different species.

children.label: xenotransplantation
children.definition: Transplantation between animals of different species.

children.label: embryo transfer
children.definition: The transfer of mammalian embryos from an in vivo or in vitro environment to a suitable host to improve pregnancy or gestational outcome in human or animal.

children.label: allografting
children.definition: Transplantation between individuals of the same species. Usually refers to genetically disparate individuals in contradistinction to isogeneic transplantation for genetically identical individuals.

children.label: tissue transplantation
children.definition: Transference of tissue within an individual, between individuals of the same species, or between individuals of different species.

children.label: bone transplantation
children.definition: The grafting of bone from a donor site to a recipient site.

children.label: skin grafting
children.definition: The grafting of skin in humans or animals from one site to another to replace a lost portion of the body surface skin.

children.label: organ transplantation
children.definition: Transference of an organ between individuals of the same species or between individuals of different species.

children.label: liver transplant
children.definition: The transference of a part of or an entire liver from one human or animal to another.

children.label: kidney transplant
children.definition: The transference of a kidney from one human or animal to another.

children.label: heart transplant
children.definition: The transference of a heart from one human or animal to another.

children.label: cell transplantation
children.definition: Transference of cells within an individual, between individuals of the same species, or between individuals of different species.

children.label: autografting
children.definition: Transplantation of an individual's own tissue from one site to another site.

children.label: laminectomy
children.definition: A surgical procedure that entails removing all (laminectomy) or part (laminotomy) of selected vertebral lamina to relieve pressure on the spinal cord and/or spinal nerve roots. Vertebral lamina is the thin flattened posterior wall of vertebral arch that forms the vertebral foramen through which pass the spinal cord and nerve roots.

children.label: gonadectomy
children.definition: The surgical removal of the gonads (ovaries, testes, or ovotestes).

children.label: castration
children.definition: The surgical removal or other physical destruction of the testes of a male animal, e.g. using elastrator bands on male lambs or piglets.

children.label: amputation
children.definition: The removal of a limb or other appendage or outgrowth of the body.

children.label: declawing
children.definition: Permanent surgical removal of the claws, usually of felines and canines.

children.label: biopsy
children.definition: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

children.label: laparotomy
children.definition: Technique of surgical incision of abdominal wall at any point; usually exploratory

children.label: endoscopy
children.definition: Procedures of applying endoscopes for disease diagnosis and treatment. Endoscopy involves passing an optical instrument through a small incision in the skin i.e. percutaneous; or through a natural orifice and along natural body pathways such as the digestive tract; and/or through an incision in the wall of a tubular structure or organ, i.e. transluminal, to examine or perform surgery on the interior parts of the body.

children.label: laparoscopy
children.definition: A procedure in which a laparoscope is inserted through a small incision near the navel to examine the abdominal and pelvic organs in the peritoneal cavity. If appropriate, biopsy or surgery can be performed during laparoscopy.

children.label: mediastinoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the anterior superior mediastinum of the thorax.

children.label: digestive tract endoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the digestive tract.

children.label: endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
children.definition: Fiberoptic endoscopy designed for duodenal observation and cannulation of Vater's ampulla, in order to visualize the pancreatic and biliary duct system by retrograde injection of contrast media. endoscopic (Vater) papillotomy (sphincterotomy, endoscopic) may be performed during this procedure.

children.label: culdoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the female pelvic viscera by means of an endoscope introduced into the pelvic cavity through the posterior vaginal fornix.

children.label: colposcopy
children.definition: The examination, therapy or surgery of the cervix and vagina by means of a specially designed endoscope introduced vaginally.

children.label: respiratory tract endoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the respiratory tract.

children.label: bronchoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the bronchi.

children.label: tracheoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the trachea.

children.label: laryngoscopy
children.definition: Examination, therapy or surgery of the interior of the larynx performed with a specially designed endoscope.

children.label: rhinoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the nasal cavity.

children.label: hysteroscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the interior of the uterus.

children.label: neuroendoscopy
children.definition: Procedures that use neuroendoscopes for diseasse diagnosis and treatment. Neuroendoscopy, generally an integration of the neuroendoscope with a computer-assisted neuronavigation system, provides guidance in neurosurgical procedures.

children.label: cystoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the urinary bladder.

children.label: angioscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery performed on the interior of blood vessels.

children.label: ureteroscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the ureter.

children.label: fetoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the fetus and amniotic cavity through abdominal or uterine entry.

children.label: arthroscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy and surgery of the joint.

children.label: thoracoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the pleural cavity.

children.label: spaying
children.definition: Removal of the ovaries and uterus of a female animal, especially a pet, for the purpose of sterilization.

children.label: surgical anastomosis
children.definition: Surgical union or shunt between ducts, tubes or vessels. It may be end-to-end, end-to-side, side-to-end, or side-to-side.

children.label: bariatric surgery
children.definition: Surgical techniques, such as gastric banding, gastric bypass, gastroplasty, and biliopancreatic diversion, performed on the stomach and/or intestines of severely obese individuals for weight reduction.

children.label: arthrodesis
children.definition: The surgical fixation of a joint by a procedure designed to accomplish fusion of the joint surfaces by promoting the proliferation of bone cells.

children.label: adrenalectomy
children.definition: Surgical removal of one or both adrenal glands.

children.label: pinealectomy
children.definition: The surgical removal of the pineal gland.

children.label: mulesing
children.definition: The surgical removal or the physical destruction of skin near the tail and perineal area of sheep in order to reduce the incidence of flystrike.

children.label: California mastitis test
children.definition: It is a simple test to diagnose mastitis in lactating animals on the basis of somatic cell count in the milk.

children.label: lethal concentration 50
children.definition: Concentration of a material in the air that kills 50% of the test animals when administered as a single exposure in a specific time period (usually 1 hour); a common measure of acute toxicity of vapors, dusts, mists and gases. Note that lethal concentration values are used when the route of administration is by inhalation. LC values are often expressed as parts of material per million parts of air (ppm). Compare "lethal dose 50".

children.label: fixed dose procedure
children.definition: This test uses a dose selected to produce signs of toxicity but not death. The aim is to set a maximum dose level beyond which no further testing is needed because the lethal dose can be predicted.

children.label: pain tests
children.definition: Tests or techniques used for measuring pain sensitivity.

children.label: tail flick test
children.definition: The tail-flick test is a test of nociception used in rats and mice. The noxious stimulus is usually radiant heat on the tail or tail immersion in hot water, and the response is a flick of the tail.

children.label: acute toxic class method
children.definition: An alternative to the LD-50 test which uses fewer animals and classifies chemicals as very toxic, toxic, harmful or unclassified.

children.label: skin tests
children.definition: Tests or bioassays that measure the skin sensitization potential of various agents or chemicals.

children.label: local lymph node assay
children.definition: This assay is an alternative method for the identification of chemicals that have the ability to cause skin sensitization and allergic contact dermatitis. Endpoints have been established so fewer animals are required and less painful procedures are used.

children.label: skin prick tests
children.definition: A test for sensitivity to allergens. A solution containing a suspected allergy-causing substance is placed on the skin and then the skin is pricked or scratched to allow the allergen to enter the skin. If the skin develops a red, raised wheal it usually means that the person is allergic to that allergen.

children.label: cryopreservation
children.definition: Preservation of cells, tissues, organs, or embryos by freezing. In histological preparations, cryopreservation or cryofixation is used to maintain the existing form, structure, and chemical composition of all the constituent elements of the specimens.

children.label: asphyxia
children.definition: A pathological condition caused by lack of oxygen, manifested in impending or actual cessation of life.

children.label: glucose tolerance tests
children.definition: A test to determine the ability of an individual to maintain homeostasis of blood glucose. It includes measuring blood glucose levels in a fasting state, and at prescribed intervals before and after oral glucose intake (75 or 100 g) or intravenous infusion (0.5 g/kg).

children.label: necropsy
children.definition: A postmortem examination to determine cause of death or to study pathology of a disease.

children.label: kidney function tests
children.definition: Laboratory tests used to evaluate how well the kidneys are working through examination of blood and urine.

children.label: pain tests
children.definition: Tests or techniques used for measuring pain sensitivity.

children.label: tail flick test
children.definition: The tail-flick test is a test of nociception used in rats and mice. The noxious stimulus is usually radiant heat on the tail or tail immersion in hot water, and the response is a flick of the tail.

children.label: plethysmography
children.definition: Recording of change in the size of a part as modified by the circulation in it.

children.label: diagnostic pneumomediastinum
children.definition: Deliberate introduction of air or gas into the mediastinum as an aid to examination and diagnosis.

children.label: exercise test
children.definition: Controlled physical activity, more strenuous than at rest, which is performed in order to allow assessment of physiological functions, particularly cardiovascular and pulmonary, but also aerobic capacity. Maximal (most intense) exercise is usually required but submaximal exercise is also used. The intensity of exercise is often graded, using criteria such as rate of work done, oxygen consumption, and heart rate.

children.label: hearing tests
children.definition: Part of an ear examination that measures the ability of sound to reach the brain.

children.label: breath tests
children.definition: Any tests done on exhaled air.

children.label: endoscopy
children.definition: Procedures of applying endoscopes for disease diagnosis and treatment. Endoscopy involves passing an optical instrument through a small incision in the skin i.e. percutaneous; or through a natural orifice and along natural body pathways such as the digestive tract; and/or through an incision in the wall of a tubular structure or organ, i.e. transluminal, to examine or perform surgery on the interior parts of the body.

children.label: laparoscopy
children.definition: A procedure in which a laparoscope is inserted through a small incision near the navel to examine the abdominal and pelvic organs in the peritoneal cavity. If appropriate, biopsy or surgery can be performed during laparoscopy.

children.label: mediastinoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the anterior superior mediastinum of the thorax.

children.label: digestive tract endoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the digestive tract.

children.label: endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
children.definition: Fiberoptic endoscopy designed for duodenal observation and cannulation of Vater's ampulla, in order to visualize the pancreatic and biliary duct system by retrograde injection of contrast media. endoscopic (Vater) papillotomy (sphincterotomy, endoscopic) may be performed during this procedure.

children.label: culdoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the female pelvic viscera by means of an endoscope introduced into the pelvic cavity through the posterior vaginal fornix.

children.label: colposcopy
children.definition: The examination, therapy or surgery of the cervix and vagina by means of a specially designed endoscope introduced vaginally.

children.label: respiratory tract endoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the respiratory tract.

children.label: bronchoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the bronchi.

children.label: tracheoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the trachea.

children.label: laryngoscopy
children.definition: Examination, therapy or surgery of the interior of the larynx performed with a specially designed endoscope.

children.label: rhinoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the nasal cavity.

children.label: hysteroscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the interior of the uterus.

children.label: neuroendoscopy
children.definition: Procedures that use neuroendoscopes for diseasse diagnosis and treatment. Neuroendoscopy, generally an integration of the neuroendoscope with a computer-assisted neuronavigation system, provides guidance in neurosurgical procedures.

children.label: cystoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the urinary bladder.

children.label: angioscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery performed on the interior of blood vessels.

children.label: ureteroscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the ureter.

children.label: fetoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the fetus and amniotic cavity through abdominal or uterine entry.

children.label: arthroscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy and surgery of the joint.

children.label: thoracoscopy
children.definition: Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the pleural cavity.

children.label: glucose clamp technique
children.definition: Maintenance of a constant blood glucose level by perfusion or infusion with glucose or insulin. It is used for the study of metabolic rates (e.g., in glucose, lipid, amino acid metabolism) at constant glucose concentration.

children.label: bioimaging
children.definition: Multi-dimensional detection, characterization and visualization of biological processes or cells.

children.label: tomography
children.definition: Imaging methods that result in sharp images of objects located on a chosen plane and blurred images located above or below the plane.

children.label: positron-emission tomography
children.definition: An imaging technique using compounds labelled with short-lived positron-emitting radionuclides (such as carbon-11, nitrogen-13, oxygen-15 and fluorine-18) to measure cell metabolism. It has been useful in study of soft tissues such as cancer; cardiovascular system; and brain.

children.label: erythrocyte sedimentation rate
children.definition: Measurement of rate of settling of erythrocytes in anticoagulated blood.

children.label: blood cell counts
children.definition: The number of leukocytes and erythrocytes per unit volume in a sample of venous blood. A complete blood count (CBC) also includes measurement of the hemoglobin; hematocrit; and erythrocyte indices.

children.label: erythrocyte count
children.definition: The number of red blood cells per unit volume in a sample of venous blood.

children.label: leukocyte count
children.definition: A count of the number of white blood cells per unit volume in venous blood. A differential leukocyte count measures the relative numbers of the different types of white cells.

children.label: hematocrit
children.definition: The volume of packed red cells in a blood specimen. The volume is measured by centrifugation in a tube with graduated markings, or with automated blood cell counters. It is an indicator of erythrocyte status in disease. For example, anemia shows a low value; polycythemia, a high value.

children.label: DNA footprinting
children.definition: A method for determining the sequence specificity of DNA-binding proteins. DNA footprinting utilizes a DNA damaging agent (either a chemical reagent or a nuclease) which cleaves DNA at every base pair.

children.label: diallel analysis
children.definition: Mating a group of genotypes in all possible combinations in order to determine the relative genetic contribution of each parent to specific characters in the offspring.

children.label: genetic markers
children.definition: A phenotypically recognizable genetic trait which can be used to identify a genetic locus, a linkage group, or a recombination event.

children.label: reverse genetics
children.definition: The use of techniques that produce a functional mutation or an effect on gene expression of a specific gene of interest in order to identify the role or activity of the gene product of that gene.

children.label: suppression subtractive hybridization
children.definition: A nucleic acid hybridization technique for investigating genetic variation by examining differential gene expression through cDNA comparisons.

children.label: DNA microarrays
children.definition: It consists of thousands of DNA spots attached to a solid support. Each spot contains multiple copies of DNA of a single gene. It is used for measuring the expression of genes of interest.

children.label: comparative genomic hybridization
children.definition: A method for comparing two sets of chromosomal DNA by analyzing differences in the copy number and location of specific sequences. It is used to look for large sequence changes such as deletions, duplications, amplifications, or translocations.

children.label: molecular cloning
children.definition: The insertion of recombinant DNA molecules from prokaryotic and/or eukaryotic sources into a replicating vehicle, such as a plasmid or virus vector, and the introduction of the resultant hybrid molecules into recipient cells without altering the viability of those cells.

children.label: gene fusion
children.definition: The genetic recombination of the parts of two or more genes resulting in a gene with different or additional regulatory regions, or a new chimeric gene product.

children.label: two hybrid system techniques
children.definition: Screening techniques first developed in yeast to identify genes encoding interacting proteins. Variations are used to evaluate interplay between proteins and other molecules. Two-hybrid techniques refer to analysis for protein-protein interactions, one-hybrid for DNA-protein interactions, three-hybrid interactions for RNA-protein interactions or ligand-based interactions.

children.label: Northern blotting
children.definition: Detection of RNA that has been electrophoretically separated and immobilized by blotting on nitrocellulose or other type of paper or nylon membrane followed by hybridization with labeled nucleic acid probes.

children.label: gene targeting
children.definition: The integration of exogenous DNA into the genome of an organism at sites where its expression can be suitably controlled. This integration occurs as a result of homologous recombination.

children.label: chromosome banding
children.definition: Staining of bands, or chromosome segments, allowing the precise identification of individual chromosomes or parts of chromosomes.

children.label: electroporation
children.definition: A technique in which electric pulses of intensity in kilovolts per centimeter and of microsecond-to-millisecond duration cause a temporary loss of the semipermeability of cell membranes, thus leading to ion leakage, escape of metabolites, and increased uptake by cells of drugs, molecular probes, and DNA.

children.label: chromosome mapping
children.definition: Any method used for determining the location of and relative distances between genes on a chromosome.

children.label: physical chromosome mapping
children.definition: Mapping of the linear order and distance of genes on a chromosome using methods other than genetic recombination.

children.label: restriction mapping
children.definition: Use of restriction endonucleases to analyze and generate a physical map of genomes, genes, or other segments of DNA.

children.label: radiation hybrid mapping
children.definition: A method for ordering genetic loci along chromosomes. The method involves fusing irradiated donor cells with host cells from another species. Following cell fusion, fragments of DNA from the irradiated cells become integrated into the chromosomes of the host cells. Molecular probing of DNA obtained from the fused cells is used to determine if two or more genetic loci are located within the same fragment of donor cell DNA.

children.label: chromosome walking
children.definition: A technique with which an unknown region of a chromosome can be explored. It is generally used to isolate a locus of interest for which no probe is available but that is known to be linked to a gene which has been identified and cloned. A fragment containing a known gene is selected and used as a probe to identify other overlapping fragments which contain the same gene. The nucleotide sequences of these fragments can then be characterized. This process continues for the length of the chromosome.

children.label: polymerase chain reaction
children.definition: In vitro method for producing large amounts of specific DNA or RNA fragments of defined length and sequence from small amounts of short oligonucleotide flanking sequences (primers).

children.label: rapid amplification of cDNA ends
children.definition: A rapid method for cloning full-length cDNA when the sequence is only partially known. cDNA copies of a region within an RNA transcript are sequenced from a small known sequence to the 5' or 3' end of the transcript.

children.label: quantitative polymerase chain reaction
children.definition: Methods used for detecting the amplified DNA products from the polymerase chain reaction as they accumulate instead of at the end of the reaction.

children.label: target region amplification polymorphism
children.definition: A PCR-based technique for genotyping germplasm which uses targeted candidate gene sequences to generate polymorphic genetic markers.

children.label: genome walking
children.definition: A polymerase chain reaction-based DNA sequencing technique for identifying unknown nucleotide sequences flanking already characterized DNA regions.

children.label: virus curing
children.definition: Causing the loss of a dormant virus which has inserted itself into a bacterial genome (a lysogenized virus).

children.label: genotyping
children.definition: Methods used to determine individuals' specific alleles or SNPs (single nucleotide polymorphisms).

children.label: multilocus sequence typing
children.definition: Direct nucleotide sequencing of gene fragments from multiple housekeeping genes for the purpose of phylogenetic analysis, organism identification, and typing of species, strain, serovar, or other distinguishable phylogenetic level.

children.label: heterologous gene expression
children.definition: Expression of a gene or genes of interest from one organism into another organism that doesn't have it. It is used for the production of biological substances (proteins, enzymes, polyketides etc.) or for other research objectives.

children.label: DNA fingerprinting
children.definition: A technique for identifying individuals of a species that is based on the uniqueness of their DNA sequence. Uniqueness is determined by identifying which combination of allelic variations occur in the individual at a statistically relevant number of different loci.

children.label: systematic evolution of ligands by exponential enrichment
children.definition: A method of generating a large library of randomized nucleotides and selecting nucleotide aptamers by iterative rounds of in vitro selection. A modified procedure substitutes amino acids in place of nucleotides to make peptide aptamers.

children.label: plasmid curing
children.definition: The treatment of cells with a substance that interferes with plasmid replication.

children.label: genetic complementation test
children.definition: A test used to determine whether or not complementation (compensation in the form of dominance) will occur in a cell with a given mutant phenotype when another mutant genome, encoding the same mutant phenotype, is introduced into that cell.

children.label: in situ hybridization
children.definition: A technique that localizes specific nucleic acid sequences within intact chromosomes, eukaryotic cells, or bacterial cells through the use of specific nucleic acid-labeled probes.

children.label: gene transfer
children.definition: The introduction of functional (usually cloned) genes into cells and organisms by a variety of techniques that may result in genetically transformed cells and individuals.

children.label: transfection
children.definition: The uptake of naked or purified DNA by cells, usually meaning the process as it occurs in eukaryotic cells. It is analogous to bacterial transformation and both are routinely employed in gene transfer techniques.

children.label: agroinfiltration
children.definition: A technique for genetic transformation of plants by injection or vacuum infiltration of Agrobacterium or a plant virus carrying a desired gene, thereby providing a system for monitoring transient gene expression.

children.label: biolistics
children.definition: Techniques where DNA is delivered directly into organelles at high speed using projectiles coated with nucleic acid, shot from a helium-powered gun (gene gun).

children.label: optogenetics
children.definition: The combination of genetic and optical methods in controlling specific events with temporal precision in targeted cells of a functioning intact biological system.

children.label: sequence analysis
children.definition: A multistage process that includes the determination of a sequence (protein, carbohydrate, etc.), its fragmentation and analysis, and the interpretation of the resulting sequence information.

children.label: multilocus sequence typing
children.definition: Direct nucleotide sequencing of gene fragments from multiple housekeeping genes for the purpose of phylogenetic analysis, organism identification, and typing of species, strain, serovar, or other distinguishable phylogenetic level.

children.label: high-throughput nucleotide sequencing
children.definition: Techniques of nucleotide sequence analysis that increase the range, complexity, sensitivity, and accuracy of results by greatly increasing the scale of operations and thus the number of nucleotides, and the number of copies of each nucleotide sequenced. The sequencing may be done by analysis of the synthesis or ligation products, hybridization to preexisting sequences, etc.

children.label: sequence homology
children.definition: The degree of similarity between sequences. Studies of amino acid and nucleotide sequences provide useful information about the genetic relatedness of certain species.

children.label: sequence alignment
children.definition: The arrangement of two or more amino acid or base sequences from an organism or organisms in such a way as to align areas of the sequences sharing common properties.

children.label: peptide mapping
children.definition: Analysis of peptides that are generated from the digestion or fragmentation of a protein or mixture of proteins, by electrophoresis; chromatography; or mass spectometry. The resulting peptide fingerprints are analyzed for a variety of purposes including the identification of the proteins in a sample, genetic polymorphisms, patterns of gene expression, and patterns diagnostic for diseases.

children.label: DNA barcoding
children.definition: Techniques for standardizing and expediting taxonomic identification or classification of organisms that are based on deciphering the sequence of one or a few regions of DNA known as the "DNA barcode".

children.label: genome assembly
children.definition: A sequencing technique in which many small DNA sequence pieces are put together using bioinformatics and computer algorithms to reconstruct the complete set of genetic material representing that in the chromosomes of an organism.

children.label: Southern blotting
children.definition: A method (first developed by E.M. Southern) for detection of DNA that has been electrophoretically separated and immobilized by blotting on nitrocellulose or other type of paper or nylon membrane followed by hybridization with labeled nucleic acid probes.

children.label: artificial pneumoperitoneum
children.definition: Deliberate introduction of air into the peritoneal cavity.

children.label: thyroid function tests
children.definition: Blood tests used to evaluate the functioning of the thyroid gland.

children.label: urinalysis
children.definition: Examination of urine by chemical, physical, or microscopic means.

children.label: psychological tests
children.definition: Standardized tests designed to measure abilities, as in intelligence, aptitude, and achievement tests, or to evaluate personality traits.

children.label: implicit association test
children.definition: Implicit association test is one of the most influential measures of the unconscious attitudes. It measures attitudes and beliefs that people may be unwilling or unable to report.

children.label: xenodiagnosis
children.definition: A method for diagnosing a disease in one organism by inoculating the putative causative organism in a second animal of a different species. It has been used for the detection of parasites (Trypanosoma cruzi and Trichinella spiralis) when peripheral blood smears are negative.

children.label: animal identification
children.definition: Procedures for recognizing individual animals and certain identifiable characteristics pertaining to them; includes computerized methods, ear tags, etc.

children.label: underwater vehicles
children.definition: Any self-powered underwater craft or towed underwater barges and arrays.

children.label: tankers
children.definition: A ship, plane, or truck constructed to transport bulk quantities of liquids, such as milk, oil, or slurries.

children.label: recreational vehicles
children.definition: Any vehicle used for traveling, temporary camping or for pleasure, such as a motor home, dune buggy, camper, etc.

children.label: unmanned aerial vehicles
children.definition: The unmanned aircraft and all of the associated support equipment, control station, data links, telemetry, communications and navigation equipment, etc., necessary to operate the unmanned aircraft.

children.label: motorcycles
children.definition: Two-wheeled, engine-driven vehicles.

children.label: sand filters
children.definition: Devices that remove some suspended solids from sewage. Air and bacteria decompose additional wastes filtering through the sand so that cleaner water drains from the bed.

children.label: cotton gin
children.definition: A machine that separates raw cotton fibers from their seeds.

children.label: combine harvesters
children.definition: Self-propelled or tractor-drawn harvesting machines which cut the standing crop (small grains, sorghum, soybeans, forage grasses, etc.), thresh the seed from the stem, separate the chaff, collect the seed, and return the straw to the ground, as they move across the field.

children.label: balers
children.definition: A machine that picks up a windrow of forage, compresses it, forms it into a rectangular or cylindrical bale, wraps it, and discharges it either onto the ground or into a trailing, convenient hauling vehicle. Bale size is highly variable among models.

children.label: tree shelters
children.definition: Tubes, usually made of plastic, that provide improved microclimate and protection against animal pests and herbicides for tree seedlings and saplings during initial establishment and growth.

children.label: chipping headrig
children.definition: A piece of machinery used in sawmills which chips away the outer portion of the log to produce wood chips and simultaneously saws the inner part into lumber.

children.label: forwarders
children.definition: A machine used in the timber industry that carries logs from the felling site to a roadside for transport without dragging them on the ground.

children.label: tillage implements
