children.definition: Field tools and machinery designed for efficient tillage of the soil, e.g., cultivators, harrows, disks and plows.

children.label: pallets
children.definition: A low wood or metal platform on which material can be stacked to facilitate mechanical handling, moving, and storage.

children.label: fluidized beds
children.definition: Bed of suspended particles (a powder or other solid particulate material) in an upward flow of air or other gas, behaving like a fluid. Effective in transferring heat or moisture between a gas and a solid, or in operating certain chemical reactions.

children.label: bioreactors
children.definition: Tools or devices for generating products using the synthetic or chemical conversion capacity of a biological system. They can be classical fermentors, cell culture perfusion systems, or enzyme bioreactors. For production of proteins or enzymes, recombinant microorganisms such as bacteria, mammalian cells, or insect or plant cells are usually chosen.

children.label: microbial fuel cells
children.definition: Device in which chemical energy is converted into electricity by microorganisms.

children.label: photobioreactors
children.definition: A closed system of plastic or glass containers which allows for the input of light, nutrients, and carbon dioxide to cultivate phototrophic microorganisms, such as microalgae. The growth environment can be more easily controlled compared to open pond cultivation, preventing water evaporation and increasing biomass productivity. However, photobioreactors often require high material and energy costs, making scalability problematic.

children.label: flatware
children.definition: The assortment of knives, forks, spoons and other implements used for eating.

children.label: cooking utensils
children.definition: The assortment of handheld implements used for the preparation of foods.

children.label: equipment maintenance and repair
children.definition: The upkeep, servicing and restoration of equipment to good working condition.

children.label: broadcasters
children.definition: A device designed to apply seeds, fertilizers or soil amendments to land. The broadcaster typically consists of a hopper from which the material is supplied to a revolving fanlike mechanism that disperses it.

children.label: lidar
children.definition: The use of reflected laser pulses to measure distance, position or velocity.

children.label: interferometers
children.definition: Instruments for measuring distances or movements by means of the phenomena caused by the interference of two rays of light (optical interferometry) or of sound (acoustic interferometry).

children.label: sodar
children.definition: Meteorological instrument used to measure the scattering of sound waves by atmospheric turbulence.

children.label: sonar
children.definition: A method or system, analogous to radar used under water, in which high frequency sound waves are emitted so as to be reflected back from objects, and used to detect the objects of interest. Called ASDIC by the British. (From SOund, NAvigation, and Ranging).

children.label: lysimeters
children.definition: Instruments for measuring the water percolating through soils and determining the materials dissolved by the water.

children.label: thermistors
children.definition: Electron devices employing the temperature dependent change of resistivity of a semiconductor.

children.label: psychrometers
children.definition: An instrument for measuring the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere. It has both a dry-bulb and wet-bulb thermometer. The bulb of the wet-bulb thermometer is kept moistened and is, therefore, cooled by evaporation to a temperature lower than that shown by the dry-bulb thermometer. Because evaporation is greater in dry air, the difference between the two thermometer readings will be greater when the air is dry than when it is moist.

children.label: detectors
children.definition: A device that automatically identifies and records a stimulus.

children.label: permeameters
children.definition: A laboratory instrument for determining permeability by measuring the discharge through a sample of the material when a known hydraulic head is applied.

children.label: radiometers
children.definition: A device that measures radiant energy and electromagnetic radiation.

children.label: Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer
strain gauges
children.definition: Instruments used to measure the strain of distortion in a member or test specimen (such as a structural part) subjected to a force.

children.label: rain gauges
children.definition: An instrument that measures the amount of rain that has fallen in a particular place.

children.label: hygrometers
children.definition: Instruments for measuring the humidity of the atmosphere.

children.label: viscometers
children.definition: Instruments that measure viscosity of a fluid.

children.label: altimeters
children.definition: Instruments for measuring altitude.

children.label: radar
children.definition: A method, system or technique of using beamed, reflected, and timed radio waves for detecting, locating, or tracking objects (such as rockets), for measuring altitude, etc., in any of various activities, such as air traffic control or guidance. The electronic equipment or apparatus used to generate, transmit, receive, and usually, to display radio scanning or locating waves, a radar set. Used for radio detection and ranging.

children.label: ground-penetrating radar
children.definition: Used in subsurface detection, a remote sensing device that transmits a radar pulse into the soil, and records differential reflection of the pulses.

children.label: Doppler radar
children.definition: Radar which utilizes the Doppler effect to determine the radial component of velocities of relative radar targets or to select targets having particular radial velocities.

children.label: amylographs
children.definition: Instruments that measure and record the change in viscosity of a heated flour-water slurry or paste due to starch gelatinization.

children.label: hydrometers
children.definition: Measuring instruments to determine the specific gravity of liquids or solutions.

children.label: direct push technology
children.definition: Direct push technologies are a category of equipment that push or drive steel rods into the ground. They are used for rapid sampling and data collection from unconsolidated soils and sediments. A tremendous variety of attachments are available that are used at the end of rods to collect geophysical data and samples.

children.label: solar collectors
children.definition: Devices that absorb and accumulate solar radiation for use as a source of energy.

children.label: safety equipment
children.definition: Equipment and devices designed to prevent or reduce the risk of injury or accidents.

children.label: hearing protectors
children.definition: Personal devices for protection of the ears from loud or high intensity noise, water, or cold. These include earmuffs and earplugs.

children.label: lidar
children.definition: The use of reflected laser pulses to measure distance, position or velocity.

children.label: telescopes
children.definition: Instruments used to observe distant objects.

children.label: diagnostic equipment
children.definition: Nonexpendable items used in examination.

children.label: prostheses
children.definition: Artificial substitutes for body parts, and materials inserted into tissue for functional, cosmetic, or therapeutic purposes. Prostheses can be functional, as in the case of artificial arms and legs, or cosmetic, as in the case of an artificial eye. Implants, all surgically inserted or grafted into the body, tend to be used therapeutically.

children.label: splints (medical)
children.definition: Rigid or flexible appliances used to maintain in position a displaced or movable part or to keep in place and protect an injured part.

children.label: catheters
children.definition: A flexible, tubular device that is used to carry fluids into or from a blood vessel, hollow organ, or body cavity.

children.label: contraceptives
children.definition: Agents, devices, methods, or procedures which diminish the likelihood of or prevent conception.

children.label: casts (medical)
children.definition: Dressings made of fiberglass, plastic, or bandage impregnated with plaster of paris used for immobilization of various parts of the body in cases of fractures, dislocations, and infected wounds.

children.label: fuel cells
children.definition: Device in which chemical energy is converted into electricity.

children.label: microbial fuel cells
children.definition: Device in which chemical energy is converted into electricity by microorganisms.

children.label: hydrogen fuel cells
children.definition: An electrochemical device in which electrons released from the oxidation of hydrogen gas as the source fuel produce an electric current.

children.label: radio transmitters
children.definition: Devices for producing radio-frequency power, for purposes of radio transmission.

children.label: electronic chips
children.definition: A small piece of silicon or other semiconducting material used to make an integrated circuit.

children.label: photovoltaic cells
children.definition: An electronic device consisting of layers of semiconductor materials fabricated to form a junction (adjacent layers of materials with different electronic characteristics) and electrical contacts and being capable of converting incident light directly into electricity (direct current).

children.label: radar
children.definition: A method, system or technique of using beamed, reflected, and timed radio waves for detecting, locating, or tracking objects (such as rockets), for measuring altitude, etc., in any of various activities, such as air traffic control or guidance. The electronic equipment or apparatus used to generate, transmit, receive, and usually, to display radio scanning or locating waves, a radar set. Used for radio detection and ranging.

children.label: ground-penetrating radar
children.definition: Used in subsurface detection, a remote sensing device that transmits a radar pulse into the soil, and records differential reflection of the pulses.

children.label: Doppler radar
children.definition: Radar which utilizes the Doppler effect to determine the radial component of velocities of relative radar targets or to select targets having particular radial velocities.

children.label: lidar
children.definition: The use of reflected laser pulses to measure distance, position or velocity.

children.label: thermistors
children.definition: Electron devices employing the temperature dependent change of resistivity of a semiconductor.

children.label: transponders
children.definition: An electronic device, named for its combined transmitter and responder capabilities, whose function is to receive a specific signal and transmit a specific reply.

children.label: capacitors
children.definition: Device for accumulating and holding a charge of electricity and consisting of conducting surfaces separated by a dielectric.

children.label: intraocular injection
children.definition: The administration of substances into the eye with a hypodermic syringe.

children.label: body water
children.definition: Fluids composed mainly of water found within the body.

children.label: eosinophils
children.definition: Granular leukocytes with a nucleus that usually has two lobes connected by a slender thread of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing coarse, round granules that are uniform in size and stainable by eosin.

children.label: heterophils
children.definition: A granulocyte in birds that corresponds to the neutrophil in man.

children.label: neutrophils
children.definition: Granular leukocytes having a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes.

children.label: mononuclear leukocytes
children.definition: Leukocytes found in the systemic circulation having large, non-lobed nuclei and lacking coarse cytoplasmic granules.

children.label: gastric juice
children.definition: The liquid secretion of the stomach mucosa consisting of hydrochloric acid (gastric acid); pepsinogens; intrinsic factor; gastrin; mucus; and the bicarbonate ion (bicarbonates).

children.label: venoms
children.definition: Poisonous animal secretions forming fluid mixtures of many different enzymes, toxins, and other substances. These substances are produced in specialized glands and secreted through specialized delivery systems (nematocysts, spines, fangs, etc.) for disabling prey or predator.

children.label: conotoxins
children.definition: Peptide neurotoxins from the marine fish-hunting snails of the genus Conus. They contain 13 to 29 amino acids which are strongly basic and are highly cross-linked by disulfide bonds. There are three types of conotoxins, omega-, alpha-, and mu-. Omega-conotoxins inhibit voltage-activated entry of calcium into the presynaptic membrane and therefore the release of acetylcholine. Alpha-conotoxins inhibit the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptor. Mu-conotoxins prevent the generation of muscle action potentials.

children.label: snake venoms
children.definition: Solutions or mixtures of toxic and nontoxic substances elaborated by snake (Ophidia) salivary glands for the purpose of killing prey or disabling predators and delivered by grooved or hollow fangs. They usually contain enzymes, toxins, and other factors.

children.label: bungarotoxins
children.definition: Neurotoxic proteins from the venom of the banded or Formosan krait (Bungarus multicinctus, an elapid snake). alpha-Bungarotoxin blocks nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and has been used to isolate and study them; beta- and gamma-bungarotoxins act presynaptically causing acetylcholine release and depletion. Both alpha and beta forms have been characterized, the alpha being similar to the large, long or Type II neurotoxins from other elapid venoms.

children.label: amphibian venoms
children.definition: Venoms produced by frogs, toads, salamanders, etc. The venom glands are usually on the skin of the back and contain cardiotoxic glycosides, cholinolytics, and a number of other bioactive materials, many of which have been characterized. The venoms have been used as arrow poisons and include bufogenin, bufotoxin, bufagin, bufotalin, histrionicotoxins, and pumiliotoxin.

children.label: intestinal secretions
children.definition: Fluids originating from the epithelial lining of the intestines, adjoining exocrine glands and from organs such as the liver, which empty into the cavity of the intestines.

children.label: skim milk
children.definition: Milk from which sufficient cream has been removed to reduce its milk fat content to less than 0.5 % (usually less than 0.1%).

children.label: low fat milk
children.definition: Milk containing at least 8.25% solids and from which sufficient milk fat has been removed to produce a milk fat content of 0.5, 1.0, or 2.0%.

children.label: feces
children.definition: Excrement from the intestines, containing unabsorbed solids, waste products, secretions, and bacteria of the digestive system.

children.label: laminae (animals)
children.definition: A thin strata or platelike structure, as one of the layers of sensitive vascular tissue between the bone and horn in the hoof of a horse.

children.label: dermis
children.definition: A layer of vascular connective tissue underneath the epidermis.

children.label: ependyma
children.definition: A thin membrane that lines the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord.

children.label: neurilemma
children.definition: The nerve husk. The outermost part of the myelin sheath covering a myelinated nerve fiber or a bundle of unmyelinated nerve fibers.

children.label: tendons
children.definition: Fibrous bands or cords of connective tissue at the ends of muscle fibers that serve to attach the muscles to bones and other structures.

children.label: stromal cells
children.definition: Connective tissue cells of an organ found in the loose connective tissue. These are most often associated with the uterine mucosa and the ovary as well as the hematopoietic system and elsewhere.

children.label: granulation tissue
children.definition: A vascular connective tissue formed on the surface of a healing wound, ulcer, or inflamed tissue. It consists of new capillaries and an infiltrate containing lymphoid cells, macrophages, and plasma cells.

children.label: fibroblasts
children.definition: Connective tissue cells which secrete an extracellular matrix rich in collagen and other macromolecules.

children.label: caudal cruciate ligament
children.definition: A ligament which, along with the cranial cruciate ligament, provides stability to the stifle joint.

children.label: cranial cruciate ligament
children.definition: A ligament which, along with the caudal cruciate ligament, provides stability to the stifle joint.

children.label: posterior cruciate ligament
children.definition: A strong ligament of the knee that originates from the anterolateral surface of the medial condyle of the femur, passes posteriorly and inferiorly between the condyles, and attaches to the posterior intercondylar area of the tibia.

children.label: anterior cruciate ligament
children.definition: A strong ligament of the knee that originates from the posteromedial portion of the lateral condyle of the femur, passes anteriorly and inferiorly between the condyles, and attaches to the depression in front of the intercondylar eminence of the tibia.

children.label: bone density
children.definition: The amount of mineral per square centimeter of bone. This is the definition used in clinical practice. Actual bone density would be expressed in grams per milliliter. It is most frequently measured by X-ray absorptiometry or tomography, X ray computed. Bone density is an important predictor for osteoporosis.

children.label: phalanges
children.definition: The bones of the fingers or toes.

children.label: scapula
children.definition: Also called the shoulder blade, it is a flat triangular bone, a pair of which form the back part of the shoulder girdle.

children.label: tarsus (bone)
children.definition: The bone(s) that comprise(s) the ankle joint.

children.label: thoracic spine
children.definition: The twelve vertebrae in the chest region of the spine, located between the sacral and lumbar vertebrae.

children.label: lumbar spine
children.definition: The lower back region of the spine between the thoracic and sacral vertebrae, consisting of five lumbar vertebrae.

children.label: cervical spine
children.definition: The neck region of the spinal column, consisting of seven cervical vertebrae.

children.label: sacral spine
children.definition: The vertebrae of the pelvic region, below the lumbar spine. These vertebrae are usually fused together to form a solid unit.

children.label: pelvic bones
children.definition: Bones that constitute each half of the pelvic girdle in vertebrates, formed by fusion of the ilium; ischium; and pubic bone.

children.label: ilium
children.definition: The largest of three bones that make up each half of the pelvic girdle.

children.label: acetabulum
children.definition: The part of the pelvis that comprises the pelvic socket where the head of femur joins to form hip joint (acetabulofemoral joint).

children.label: pubic bone
children.definition: A bone that forms the lower and anterior part of each side of the hip bone.

children.label: ischium
children.definition: One of three bones that make up the coxal bone of the pelvic girdle. In tetrapods, it is the part of the pelvis that projects backward on the ventral side, and in primates, it bears the weight of the sitting animal.

children.label: epiphyses
children.definition: The head of a long bone that is separated from the shaft by the epiphyseal plate until bone growth stops. At that time, the plate disappears and the head and shaft are united.

children.label: clavicle
children.definition: A bone on the ventral side of the shoulder girdle, which in humans is commonly called the collar bone.

children.label: blubber
children.definition: A thick layer of insulating adipose tissue found beneath the skin of aquatic mammals such as whales, seals, walruses and manatees.

children.label: adenoids
children.definition: A collection of lymphoid nodules on the posterior wall and roof of the nasopharynx.

children.label: gingiva
children.definition: Oral tissue surrounding and attached to teeth.

children.label: peritoneum
children.definition: A membrane of squamous epithelial cells, the mesothelial cells, covered by apical microvilli that allow rapid absorption of fluid and particles in the peritoneal cavity. The peritoneum is divided into parietal and visceral components. The parietal peritoneum covers the inside of the abdominal wall. The visceral peritoneum covers the intraperitoneal organs. The double-layered peritoneum forms the mesentery that suspends these organs from the abdominal wall.

children.label: gastric mucosa
children.definition: Lining of the stomach, consisting of an inner epithelium, a middle lamina propria, and an outer muscularis mucosae. The surface cells produce mucus that protects the stomach from attack by digestive acid and enzymes. When the epithelium invaginates into the lamina propria at various regions of the stomach, different tubular gastric glands are formed. These glands consist of cells that secrete mucus, enzymes, hydrochloric acid, or hormones.

children.label: intestinal mucosa
children.definition: The epithelial membrane that lines the intestines, producing mucus at its free border.

children.label: goblet cells
children.definition: A glandular epithelial cell or a unicellular gland. Goblet cells secrete mucus. They are scattered in the epithelial linings of many organs, especially the small intestine and the respiratory tract.

children.label: respiratory mucosa
children.definition: The mucous membrane lining the respiratory tract, including the nasal cavity; the larynx; the trachea; and the bronchi tree. The respiratory mucosa consists of various types of epithelial cells ranging from ciliated columnar to simple squamous, mucous goblet cells, and glands containing both mucous and serous cells.

children.label: myocardium
children.definition: The muscle tissue of the heart. It is composed of striated, involuntary muscle cells connected to form the contractile pump to generate blood flow.

children.label: pectoralis muscle
children.definition: A network of tubules and sacs in the cytoplasm of skeletal muscle fibers that assist with muscle contraction and relaxation by releasing and storing calcium ions.

children.label: psoas muscles
children.definition: A powerful flexor of the thigh at the hip joint (psoas major) and a weak flexor of the trunk and lumbar spinal column (psoas minor). Psoas is derived from the Greek "psoa", the plural meaning "muscles of the loin". It is a common site of infection manifesting as abscess (psoas abscess). The psoas muscles and their fibers are also used frequently in experiments in muscle physiology.

children.label: hamstring muscles
children.definition: A group of muscles in the posterior thigh area that are involved in connecting the knee joint and the pelvis.

children.label: semimembranosus muscle
children.definition: A large muscle on the posterior thigh that runs from the base of the pelvis to the back of the tibia. It helps in bending the leg and straightening the thigh.

children.label: tonsils
children.definition: A round-to-oval mass of lymphoid tissue embedded in the lateral wall of the pharynx. There is one on each side of the oropharynx in the fauces between the anterior and posterior pillars of the soft palate.

children.label: blood sampling
children.definition: The taking of a blood sample to determine its character as a whole, to identify levels of its component cells, chemicals, gases, or other constituents, to perform pathological examination, etc.

children.label: National Center for the Replacement, Refinement and Reduction of Animals in Research
children.definition: The NC3Rs is a UK-based scientific organisation dedicated to replacing, refining and reducing the use of animals in research and testing (the 3Rs).

children.label: labor unions
children.definition: Association of workers formed for the purpose of collective bargaining with employers for the benefit of the workers, such as wages, working conditions, etc.

children.label: Center for Alternatives to Animal Testing
children.definition: CAAT promote humane science by supporting the creation, development, validation, and use of alternatives to animals in research, product safety testing, and education.

children.label: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee
agricultural experiment stations
children.definition: Centers where scientific research is conducted in order to improve food and agricultural production. Experiment station scientists and staff work with farmers and other members of the agriculture and food industry.

children.label: water users associations
children.definition: An organization whose members pool resources in a cooperative effort to manage, operate, monitor and maintain a water source or irrigation system.

children.label: National Center for the Replacement Refinement and Reduction of Animals in Research
Fund for the Replacement of Animals in Medical Experiments
Future Farmers of America
children.definition: An organization for high school students studying vocational agriculture.

children.label: Research and Education Center for Tropical Agriculture
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee
Inter-American Institute for Cooperation on Agriculture
International Organization for Standardization
children.definition: Worldwide organization consisting of a network of the national standards institutes of countries formed to promote development of standards to facilitate the international carriage and exchange of goods and service and to develop mutual cooperation in the spheres of intellectual, scientific, technological, and economic activities.

children.label: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
The Nature Conservancy
children.definition: An international conservation organization that purchases lands in order to preserve plants, animals and natural communities.

children.label: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
United Nations Environment Programme
children.definition: International environmental program administered by the United Nations whose mission is to lead countries in efforts to care for the environment.

children.label: World Organization for Animal Health
children.definition: The World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) is the intergovernmental organisation responsible for improving animal health worldwide and fighting animal diseases at a global level.

children.label: Association for Assessment and Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care International
children.definition: AAALAC International is a private, nonprofit organization that promotes the humane treatment of animals in science through voluntary accreditation and assessment programs.

children.label: International Union of Forest Research Organization
Animal Welfare Institute
children.definition: The Animal Welfare Institute is an American, non-profit, charitable organization founded in 1951 with the goal of reducing pain and fear inflicted on animals by humans. Its legislative division, the Society for Animal Protective Legislation, pushes for the passage of laws that reflect this purpose.

children.label: American Society for Cellular and Computational Toxicology
children.definition: The American Society for Cellular and Computational Toxicology (ASCCT) is a scientific society dedicated to the promotion of toxicology testing and research that reduces and replaces the use of animals.

children.label: American Association for Laboratory Animal Science
children.definition: American Association for Laboratory Animal Science (AALAS) is an association of professionals that advances responsible laboratory animal care and use to benefit people and animals.

children.label: Interagency Coordinating Committee on the Validation of Alternative Methods
trade associations
children.definition: An organization comprised of businesses, manufacturers and individuals who are in the same trade or industry and have organized in order to promote common interests, such as promotion of an industry or adoption of standards within an industry.

children.label: United States Army Corps of Engineers
U.S. Cooperative Extension Service
children.definition: A national, publicly funded, nonformal education network that links the educational and research resources and activities of USDA with land grant universities in every State, territory, and the District of Columbia. The Federal partner is the Cooperative State Research, Education, and Extension Service. This unique Federal, State, and local partnership focuses on practical solutions to critical issues affecting people's daily lives.

children.label: Interagency Coordinating Committee on the Validation of Alternative Methods
United States Agency for International Development
Interagency Risk Assessment Consortium
children.definition: An association of representatives from federal agencies, institutes and centers who collectively work to further research, coordination, and communication in the area of food safety risk assessment.

children.label: Department of Health and Human Services
National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences
children.definition: The National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS) Superfund Basic Research Program, provides funding to 18 programs at 70 universities and institutions around the United States to study the human health effects of hazardous substances in the environment, especially those found at uncontrolled, leaking waste disposal sites.

children.label: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Farm Credit Administration
children.definition: As an independent agency in the Executive Branch of the U.S. Government, it is responsible for the regulation and examination of the Farm Credit System.

children.label: National Institute of Food and Agriculture
children.definition: An agency within U.S. Department of Agriculture formerly known as the Cooperative State Research, Education, and Extension Service, and renamed to the National Institute of Food and Agriculture on September 30, 2009.

children.label: Nutrition Evidence Systematic Review
children.definition: USDA's Nutrition Evidence Systematic Review (NESR), formerly the Nutrition Evidence Library (NEL), specializes in conducting food- and nutrition-related systematic reviews. NESR systematic reviews are research projects that answer important public health questions by using rigorous and transparent methods to search for, evaluate, analyze, and synthesize the body of scientific evidence on topics relevant to Federal policy and programs.

children.label: USDA National Agricultural Library
children.definition: One of five national libraries of the United States, housing one of the world's largest agricultural information collections which covers all aspects of agriculture and related sciences.

children.label: Long-Term Agroecosystem Research Network
children.definition: It is a partnership among 18 premier long-term research sites across the United States. LTAR was established to build the knowledge required for sustainable intensification of agriculture, increasing yields from the current agricultural land base while minimizing or reversing agricultureâ€™s adverse environmental impacts. Network research is organized around topics of sustainability of regional or national consequence, relying upon long-term databases, cross-site experiments, and computational modeling to tie experimental and monitoring conclusions from diverse locations to a broader vision of agriculture for the United States.

children.label: USDA National Plant Germplasm System
children.definition: The U.S. National Plant Germplasm System (NPGS) is collaborative effort to safeguard the genetic diversity of agriculturally important plants. The NPGS is managed by the Agricultural Research Service (ARS), the in-house research agency of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA).

children.label: Center for Nutrition Policy and Promotion
Farm Service Agency
children.definition: Stabilizing farm income, helping farmers conserve land and water resources, providing credit to new or disadvantaged farmers and ranchers, and helping farm operations recover from the effects of disaster are the missions of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency (FSA).

children.label: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
Grain Inspection Packers and Stockyards Administration
Time to Incorporate to Nest Test (TINT)
anti-inflammatory agents
children.definition: Substances that reduce or suppress inflammation.

children.label: sulfasalazine
children.definition: A drug that is used in the management of inflammatory bowel diseases. Its activity is generally considered to lie in its metabolic breakdown product, 5-aminosalicylic acid released in the colon.

children.label: prednisolone
children.definition: A glucocorticoid with the general properties of the corticosteroids. It is the drug of choice for all conditions in which routine systemic corticosteroid therapy is indicated, except adrenal deficiency states.

children.label: cholinergic agents
children.definition: Any drug used for its actions on cholinergic systems. Included here are agonists and antagonists, drugs that affect the life cycle of acetylcholine, and drugs that affect the survival of cholinergic neurons.

children.label: isoflurane
children.definition: A stable, non-explosive inhalation anesthetic, relatively free from significant side effects.

children.label: distress
children.definition: An adverse effect on humans or animals when they cannot escape from or adapt to physical or mental stress.

children.label: fluoxetine
children.definition: The first highly specific serotonin uptake inhibitor. It is used as an antidepressant and often has a more acceptable side-effects profile than traditional antidepressants.

children.label: tranquilizers
children.definition: A traditional grouping of drugs said to have a soothing or calming effect on mood, thought, or behavior. Included here are the anti-anxiety agents (minor tranquilizers), antimanic agents, and the antipsychotic agents (major tranquilizers). These drugs act by different mechanisms and are used for different therapeutic purposes.

children.label: animal stress
children.definition: Physical reaction to danger, threat of harm, or lack of nutrition or hydration.

children.label: analgesics
children.definition: Compounds capable of relieving pain without the loss of consciousness.

children.label: butorphanol
children.definition: A synthetic morphinan analgesic with narcotic antagonist action. It is used in the management of severe pain.

children.label: morphine
children.definition: The principal alkaloid in opium and the prototype opiate analgesic and narcotic. Morphine has widespread effects in the central nervous system and on smooth muscle.

children.label: buprenorphine
children.definition: A derivative of the opioid alkaloid thebaine that is a more potent and longer lasting analgesic than morphine. It appears to act as a partial agonist at mu and kappa opioid receptors and as an antagonist at delta receptors. The lack of delta-agonist activity has been suggested to account for the observation that buprenorphine tolerance may not develop with chronic use.

children.label: acetaminophen
children.definition: Analgesic antipyretic derivative of acetanilide. It has weak anti-inflammatory properties and is used as a common analgesic, but may cause liver, blood cell, and kidney damage.

children.label: narcotics
children.definition: Agents that induce narcosis. This term is considered outdated due to imprecision but continues to be widely used. Originally, agents that caused somnolence or induced sleep (stupor); now, any derivative, natural or synthetic, of opium or morphine or any substance that has their effects. Narcotics are potent inducers of analgesia and opioid-related disorders.

children.label: pain
children.definition: An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by nerve endings of nociceptive neurons.

children.label: colic
children.definition: A clinical syndrome with intermittent abdominal pain characterized by sudden onset and cessation. It is usually associated with obstruction of the intestines; of the cystic duct; or of the urinary tract.

children.label: hypercapnia
children.definition: A clinical manifestation of abnormal increase in the amount of carbon dioxide in arterial blood.

children.label: bloat
children.definition: A severe distension of the abdomen caused by gas; usually in ruminant animals. The problem is greatest with sudden access to lush pastures or vegetative stage alfalfa--foods that are too easily digested.

children.label: dysoxia
children.definition: Abnormal oxygen metabolism in cells and tissues.

children.label: halitosis
children.definition: An offensive, foul breath odor resulting from a variety of causes such as poor oral hygiene, dental or oral infections, or the ingestion of certain foods.

children.label: edema
children.definition: Abnormal fluid accumulation in tissues or body cavities. Most cases of edema are present under the skin in subcutaneous tissue.

children.label: asphyxia
children.definition: A pathological condition caused by lack of oxygen, manifested in impending or actual cessation of life.

children.label: jaundice
children.definition: A clinical manifestation of hyperbilirubinemia, characterized by yellowish staining of the skin; mucous membrane; and sclera. Clinical jaundice usually is a sign of liver dysfunction.

children.label: hypoxia
children.definition: Relatively complete absence of oxygen in one or more tissues.

children.label: analgesia
children.definition: Methods of pain relief that may be used with or in place of analgesics.

children.label: electronarcosis
children.definition: Profound stupor produced by passing an electric current through the brain.

children.label: animal use alternatives
children.definition: Alternatives to the use of animals in research, testing, and education. The alternatives may include reduction in the number of animals used, replacement of animals with a non-animal model or with animals of a species lower phylogenetically, or refinement of methods to minimize pain and distress of animals used.

children.label: allied health professionals
children.definition: Health care workers specially trained and licensed to assist and support the work of health professionals. Often used synonymously with paramedical personnel, the term generally refers to all health care workers who perform tasks which must otherwise be performed by a physician or other health professional.

children.label: diabetes educators
children.definition: A health care professional who teaches people who have diabetes how to manage their diabetes.

children.label: minority students
children.definition: Students who are members of minority groups.

children.label: students with disabilities
children.definition: Students who have a disability or impairment of any type that interferes with their daily usual activities and are unable to perform certain functions as most others. They may need some special accomodations.

children.label: animal well-being
children.definition: The current state of an animal living in reasonable harmony with its environment.

children.label: macroeconomics
children.definition: Economic studies or statistics that consider aggregates of individuals or groups of commodities; for example, total consumption, employment, or income.

children.label: private sector
children.definition: That distinct portion of the institutional, industrial, or economic structure of a country that is controlled or owned by non-governmental, private interests.

children.label: public sector
children.definition: The area of a nation's economy that is tax-supported and under government control.

children.label: secondary sector
children.definition: The part of a country or region's economy that produces commodities without much direct use of natural resources.

children.label: tertiary sector
children.definition: The part of a country or region's economy that produces services or assets lacking a tangible and storable form.

children.label: primary sector
children.definition: That part of a country's or region's economy that makes direct use of natural resources, including agriculture, forestry, fishing and the fuel, metal and mining industries.

children.label: monopsony
children.definition: The only buyer with control over market purchases.

children.label: concentration (economics)
children.definition: A measure of the degree to which a few large firms dominate total sales, production or capacity within an industry or market.

children.label: surface mining
children.definition: Surface mining is a very broad term and refers to any process of removing the earth, rock, and other strata in order to uncover the underlying mineral or fuel deposit.

children.label: food service
children.definition: The practice or business of making, transporting, and serving or dispensing prepared foods, as in a restaurant or school.

children.label: industrial food service
children.definition: restaurants, snack bars, cafes, etc. located at places of business for use, primarily, by their employees.

children.label: Food and Drug Administration Food Code
children.definition: A reference by the Food and Drug Administration guiding retailers like restaurants and grocery stores and institutions such as nursing homes on how to prevent foodborne illness.

children.label: temporary food service
children.definition: A quantity food prepration operation that is established with the intent of operating for a brief period of time for example: the provision of food to relief workers, church or community suppers or picnics, bake sales, etc.

children.label: transport food service
children.definition: food services (restaurants, snack bars, dining cars, individual service, etc.) provided on airplanes, trains, ships, etc. for their passengers.

children.label: tourism
children.definition: The industry that provides local entertainment, accommodation, transportation, catering and other services to visitors and travelers.

children.label: agritourism
children.definition: A form of commercial enterprise that links agricultural production and/or processing with tourism in order to attract visitors onto a farm, ranch, or other agricultural business for the purposes of entertaining and/or educating the visitors and generating income for the farm, ranch, or business owner.

children.label: ecotourism
children.definition: Travel to natural settings with focus on the appreciation, conservation, preservation and sustainability of the area's natural resources and its surrounding community.

children.label: electric utilities
children.definition: A corporation, person, agency, authority, or other legal entity or instrumentality aligned with distribution facilities for delivery of electric energy for use primarily by the public. Included are investor-owned electric utilities, municipal and State utilities, Federal electric utilities, and rural electric cooperatives. A few entities that are tariff based and corporately aligned with companies that own distribution facilities are also included.

children.label: agricultural industry
children.definition: The Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting sector comprises establishments primarily engaged in growing crops, raising animals, harvesting timber, and harvesting fish and other animals from a farm, ranch, or their natural habitats.

children.label: food industry
children.definition: The industry concerned with processing, preparing, preserving, distributing, and serving of foods and beverages.

children.label: food service
children.definition: The practice or business of making, transporting, and serving or dispensing prepared foods, as in a restaurant or school.

children.label: industrial food service
children.definition: restaurants, snack bars, cafes, etc. located at places of business for use, primarily, by their employees.

children.label: Food and Drug Administration Food Code
children.definition: A reference by the Food and Drug Administration guiding retailers like restaurants and grocery stores and institutions such as nursing homes on how to prevent foodborne illness.

children.label: temporary food service
children.definition: A quantity food prepration operation that is established with the intent of operating for a brief period of time for example: the provision of food to relief workers, church or community suppers or picnics, bake sales, etc.

children.label: transport food service
children.definition: food services (restaurants, snack bars, dining cars, individual service, etc.) provided on airplanes, trains, ships, etc. for their passengers.

children.label: fish industry
children.definition: Industry involved with the harvesting, processing, marketing, and distribution of fish, shellfish, molluscs and other aquatic organisms of commercial value.

children.label: fish discards
children.definition: Caught fish which are returned to the sea, alive or dead; these include all or a portion of the bycatch, and may or may not have been brought on board by fishermen.

children.label: artisanal fishing
children.definition: Fishing practices using traditional (low-technology) fishing boats and gear for local, small-scale food subsistence.

children.label: overfishing
children.definition: Extensive fisheries activities that are beyond the capacity for the population to replenish their stocks. Overfishing upsets the aquatic ecosystem and leads to depletion of biological resources.

children.label: bycatch
children.definition: Species caught inadvertently by fishermen during the capture of another species.

children.label: pharmaceutical industry
children.definition: That segment of commercial enterprise devoted to the design, development, and manufacture of chemical products for use in the diagnosis and treatment of disease, disability, or other dysfunction, or to improve function.

children.label: monopoly
children.definition: The only seller with control over market sales.

children.label: oligopoly
children.definition: A market in which a few sellers exert control over a large number of buyers. It is opposite of an oligopsony.

children.label: oligopsony
children.definition: A market in which a few number of buyers exert power over a large number of sellers. It is opposite of an oligopoly.

children.label: privatization
children.definition: Process of shifting publicly controlled services and/or facilities to the private sector.

children.label: market structure
children.definition: Characteristics of an industry that relate to its economic performance, such as the number of buyers and sellers, product differentiation among firms, barriers to entry, costs, degree of integration and diversification.

children.label: market microstructure
children.definition: The branch of economics that studies the pricing and trading mechanisms of assets in a market.

children.label: vertical integration
children.definition: Coordination of various levels of producing, processing and distributing under one decision making unit, generally through direct ownership of the different stages or through contracts.

children.label: Census of Agriculture
children.definition: A count taken every 5 years of the number of farms, land in farms, crop acreage and production, livestock numbers and production, farm expenses, farm facilities and equipment, farm tenure, value of farm products sold, farm size, type of farm, farm operator characteristics (age, race, sex), etc. Data are obtained for States and counties. USDA now administers the Census of Agriculture, which was previously done by the U.S. Bureau of the Census.

children.label: food loss
children.definition: The edible amount of food, postharvest, that is available for human consumption but is not consumed for any reason. It includes cooking loss and natural shrinkage (for example moisture loss); loss from mold, pests, or inadequate climate control; and food waste.

children.label: precision agriculture
children.definition: A management strategy that utilizes site-specific information to precisely and economically manage and optimize production inputs.

children.label: farm structure
children.definition: The analysis of who contributes the land, labor and capital resources required for agricultural production and how the financial rewards are distributed among those participants.

children.label: foodshed
children.definition: The geographical area delimiting local and/or regional production, transport, marketing, delivery and supply of food to a population, analogous to a watershed in its description of a geographical food system.

children.label: food justice
children.definition: A movement for ensuring that all individuals have access to healthy, low cost, good quality, locally grown, culturally relevant and nutritious food.

children.label: food sovereignty
children.definition: The right of farmers, communities, countries to define their own food and agricultural policies or systems.

children.label: parity (economics)
children.definition: A level for agricultural commodity prices maintained by governmental support and intended to give farmers the same purchasing power they had during a selected base period.

children.label: agricultural productivity
children.definition: The efficiency with which inputs are transformed into outputs in the agricultural sector. Agricultural productivity is driven by innovations in on farm tasks, changes in the organization and structure of the farm sector, research aimed at improvements in farm production, and/or random events like weather.

children.label: crop acreage
children.definition: Acres of a specific crop planted in a cropping season by farmers.

children.label: cropland harvested
children.definition: Includes row crops and closely sown crops; hay and silage crops; tree fruits, small fruits, berries, and tree nuts; vegetables and melons; and miscellaneous other minor crops. This category includes Christmas tree farms.

children.label: crop failure
children.definition: Consists mainly of the acreage on which crops failed because of weather, insects, and diseases but does include some land not harvested due to lack of labor, low market prices, or other factors. Crop failure is calculated using the difference between cropland planted and cropland harvested. However, some cropland planted is not intended to be harvested. Thus, the acreage planted to cover and soil-improvement crops not intended for harvest is excluded from crop failure and is considered idle.

children.label: food security
children.definition: Access by all people, at all times to sufficient food for an active and healthy life. Food security includes at a minimum: the ready availability of nutritionally adequate and safe foods, and an assured ability to acquire acceptable foods in socially acceptable ways.

children.label: farms
children.definition: Any establishment that normally produces and sells agricultural products.

children.label: commercial farms
children.definition: farms which produce crops and livestock primarily for sale.

children.label: small farms
children.definition: Farms with less than $250,000 gross receipts annually, on which day-to-day labor and management are provided by the farmer and/or the farm family that owns the production or owns, or leases, the productive assets.

children.label: family farms
children.definition: An agricultural business which (1) produces agricultural commodities for sale in such quantities so as to be recognized as a farm rather than a rural residence; (2) produces enough income (including off farm employment) to pay family and farm operating expenses, to pay debts, and to maintain the property; (3) is managed by the operator; (4) has a substantial amount of labor provided by the operator and family; and (5) may use seasonal labor during peak periods and a reasonable amount of full-time hired labor.

children.label: cash grain farms
children.definition: A farm where corn, grain sorghum, small grains, soybeans, or field peas and beans account for at least 50% of the value of farm products sold.

children.label: local food systems
children.definition: Local food systems are collaborative efforts that integrate food production, processing, marketing/distribution and consumption within a given geographical area, place or community. Local food systems may also be characterized by certain market and non-market distribution channels: farm direct marketing channels including farmer's markets, community supported agriculture (CSA), farm-to-institution programs; community and home gardening; and gleaning programs.

children.label: food deserts
children.definition: Food deserts are defined as urban neighborhoods and rural towns without ready access to fresh, healthy, and affordable food. Instead of supermarkets and grocery stores, these communities may have no food access or are served only by fast food restaurants and convenience stores that offer few healthy, affordable food options.

children.label: farm to school
children.definition: Farm to school is an initiative that connects children to local farms that produce fresh, healthy and minimally processed foods that are served at their schools. It also provides educational opportunities related to agriculture, health and nutrition.

children.label: farm to fork
children.definition: A description of all steps in the process, from beginning to end, involving the production, processing, packaging, handling, storage, preservation, distribution and preparation of a food product.

children.label: tariffs
children.definition: Charges assessed by a government on imported items at their point of customs entry into the country, and paid for by the importer.

children.label: ad valorem duty
children.definition: Tariff defined as a percentage of the value of an imported commodity or product.

children.label: bound tariffs
children.definition: The most-favored-nation tariff resulting from negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and incorporated as the integral component of a country's schedule of concessions; a commitment not to raise a tariff above a specified level.

children.label: import quotas
children.definition: A quantitative limit placed on the importation of specific commodities.

children.label: market access
children.definition: The extent to which a good or a service can compete with locally-made products in another market.

children.label: trade agreements
children.definition: A negotiated agreement usually among two or more countries or regions to limit or alter their policies with respect to trade.

children.label: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
children.definition: A post- World War II international treaty for the regulation of trade policy and the reduction of tariffs and trade barriers which was subsumed into the World Trade Organization in 1995.

children.label: free trade
children.definition: A policy in international markets allowing unrestricted exchange of goods between countries without the imposition of special taxes and government interference.

children.label: export subsidies
children.definition: A direct or indirect compensation provided by governments to private commercial firms to promote exports of domestic products.

children.label: currency exchange rate
children.definition: The price that one currency converts to another. Nominal exchange rates are the current value of the foreign currency in terms of U.S. dollars.

children.label: foreign exchange
children.definition: Transactions related to international money (currency) traded from one country to another by governments or businesses.

children.label: economic depression
children.definition: A multi-year extended period of declining economic growth which is typically seen as being more severe than an economic recession, e.g., gross domestic product declines by more than 10 percent.

children.label: economic recession
children.definition: The contraction phase of the business cycle lasting for a few months to several years. A recession is generally viewed as an economic downturn that is less severe than a economic depression.

children.label: Census of Agriculture
children.definition: A count taken every 5 years of the number of farms, land in farms, crop acreage and production, livestock numbers and production, farm expenses, farm facilities and equipment, farm tenure, value of farm products sold, farm size, type of farm, farm operator characteristics (age, race, sex), etc. Data are obtained for States and counties. USDA now administers the Census of Agriculture, which was previously done by the U.S. Bureau of the Census.

children.label: inflation
children.definition: An increase in the general price level of an economy. Inflation occurs when the quantity of money in circulation rises relative to the quantity of goods and services offered. The result is "too much money chasing too few goods," and prices are bid up. At high rates of inflation, people tend to lose confidence in money, and the quantity of money in circulation increases relative to expenditures in current prices as people tend to hold (hoard) goods rather than money. Inflation is associated with a rise in gross national expenditure at current prices that is greater than the increase in the real supply of goods and services available.

children.label: willingness to pay
children.definition: The amount consumers are prepared to pay for goods or services, in light of risks and/or benefits.

children.label: consumer surplus
children.definition: In economics, the difference between the price that a consumer pays for a good or a service and the amount that he would be willing to pay rather than be deprived of the good or service.

children.label: affordability
children.definition: Being able to bear the cost or to have the financial means for purchasing goods or services.

children.label: consumer demand
children.definition: The consumer's desire to possess a commodity conditioned by willingness and ability to pay.

children.label: consumer expenditure
children.definition: The goods and services purchased by consumers at the local, regional, or national level. Consumer expenditure data is usually reported in broad categories such as the amount of money spent on food at home, restaurant meals, apparel, transportation, entertainment, healthcare, household goods, etc.

children.label: economic behavior
children.definition: The predicted or observable activity or manner in which decisions are made regarding the management of wealth, including the manner of buying/selling goods and services, generating income, allocating economic resources, borrowing/lending, investment and other financial choices.

children.label: agricultural productivity
children.definition: The efficiency with which inputs are transformed into outputs in the agricultural sector. Agricultural productivity is driven by innovations in on farm tasks, changes in the organization and structure of the farm sector, research aimed at improvements in farm production, and/or random events like weather.

children.label: crop acreage
children.definition: Acres of a specific crop planted in a cropping season by farmers.

children.label: cropland harvested
children.definition: Includes row crops and closely sown crops; hay and silage crops; tree fruits, small fruits, berries, and tree nuts; vegetables and melons; and miscellaneous other minor crops. This category includes Christmas tree farms.

children.label: crop failure
children.definition: Consists mainly of the acreage on which crops failed because of weather, insects, and diseases but does include some land not harvested due to lack of labor, low market prices, or other factors. Crop failure is calculated using the difference between cropland planted and cropland harvested. However, some cropland planted is not intended to be harvested. Thus, the acreage planted to cover and soil-improvement crops not intended for harvest is excluded from crop failure and is considered idle.

children.label: gross national product
children.definition: The value of all final goods and services produced during a year by the factors in a country. It is the sum of expenditures by consumers and governments, gross investment spending, and total merchandise exports less imports.

children.label: gross domestic product
children.definition: The value of the total final output of goods and services produced inside a country during a given year. It equals gross national product (GNP) less overseas remittances.

children.label: production costs
children.definition: The sum, measured in dollars, of all purchased inputs and other expenses necessary to produce farm products. Cost of production statistics may be expressed as an average per animal, per acre, or per unit of production (bushel, pound, or hundredweight) for all farms in an area or in the country.

children.label: yield components
children.definition: Plant parts contributing to yield based on their number, size and weight.

children.label: lint yield
children.definition: The quantity of cotton fiber produced per unit of land.

children.label: attainable yield
children.definition: Yields expected through use of known technology.

children.label: economic productivity
children.definition: Capacity of a system to produce high levels of output or responsiveness of the output of a system to inputs.

children.label: supply chain
children.definition: The network of firms that bring products to market, from companies that produce raw materials to retailers and others that deliver finished products to consumers. Economic value is added through the coordinated management of the flow of physical goods and associated information at each stage of the chain.

children.label: cold chain
children.definition: A temperature-controlled supply chain.

children.label: supply chain disruptions
children.definition: Supply chain disruptions are unplanned and unexpected events that slow or stop the normal flow of goods or services in a supply chain. Usually these disruptions are often recovered within a finite, desired time.

children.label: farm to school
children.definition: Farm to school is an initiative that connects children to local farms that produce fresh, healthy and minimally processed foods that are served at their schools. It also provides educational opportunities related to agriculture, health and nutrition.

children.label: farm to fork
children.definition: A description of all steps in the process, from beginning to end, involving the production, processing, packaging, handling, storage, preservation, distribution and preparation of a food product.

children.label: value added
children.definition: The enhancement given a product or service represented by the final value of the product minus the value of all intermediate inputs.

children.label: subsidies
children.definition: Payment or benefit given to partially offset the cost of specific activities, such as the manufacture, production, or export of an article.

children.label: export subsidies
children.definition: A direct or indirect compensation provided by governments to private commercial firms to promote exports of domestic products.

children.label: public services and goods
children.definition: Services and products provided to the general public.

children.label: excise tax
children.definition: Tax imposed on the manufacture and distribution of specific nonessential consumer goods, such as cigarettes and fuel.

children.label: estate tax
children.definition: Tax imposed on the transfer of property from a deceased person to his/her heirs, legatees or devisees.

children.label: sales tax
children.definition: Tax imposed on the retail price of an item which is collected by the retailer.

children.label: infrastructure
children.definition: The basic facilities, services, and structures needed for the functioning of a community, country or area, including public transportation and roads, telecommunications systems, public water systems, power lines, and public institutions including schools, post offices, and prisons.

children.label: electric utilities
children.definition: A corporation, person, agency, authority, or other legal entity or instrumentality aligned with distribution facilities for delivery of electric energy for use primarily by the public. Included are investor-owned electric utilities, municipal and State utilities, Federal electric utilities, and rural electric cooperatives. A few entities that are tariff based and corporately aligned with companies that own distribution facilities are also included.

children.label: community feeding centers
children.definition: Organizations or facilities that prepare or assemble meals for distribution either onsite or offsite to needy recipients who do not reside on the premises. The meals are provided at little or no cost.

children.label: waterways
children.definition: Use for a navigable body of water.

children.label: vegetated waterways
children.definition: Grassed waterways are constructed graded channels that are seeded to grass or other suitable vegetation. The vegetation slows the water and the grassed waterway conveys the water to a stable outlet at a non-erosive velocity.

children.label: child development centers
children.definition: Educational facilities for preschool children, which also provide health and family services- originally used in connection with Project Head Start for centers in which cooperation of family, community, and professional staff contribute to the total development of the child.

children.label: veterinary schools
children.definition: Educational institutions for individuals specializing in the field of veterinary medicine.

children.label: preschools
children.definition: Schools for preschool children, usually 2 1/2 to 5 1/2 years of age-- nursery school programs are either part-day or part-week and may be operated as a service by public schools, or for profit by other agencies or individuals.

children.label: small schools
children.definition: Although the designation of "small" is relative to locale, small schools of grades K-12 usually do not exceed 750 students.

children.label: agricultural colleges
children.definition: Educational institutions offering a curriculum in agricultural sciences.

children.label: tribal colleges
children.definition: Post-secondary educational institutions on tribal lands in the United States; Native American colleges given land grant status by an Act of Congress in 1994 are known as the 1994 Institutions.

children.label: rural utilities
children.definition: The delivery of public services such as water, electricity, gas, telephone and telecommunications to rural communities.

children.label: assisted living facilities
children.definition: A housing and health care alternative combining independence with personal care. It provides a combination of housing, personalized supportive services and health care designed to meet the needs, both scheduled and unscheduled, of those who need help with activities of daily living.

children.label: public housing
children.definition: Housing which is typically provided to low-income persons or families, and is owned and operated by a government.

children.label: child care centers
children.definition: Facilities providing care for school-age or pre-school children.

children.label: green infrastructure
children.definition: An interconnected framework of natural and/or engineered areas, structures, facilities, features or services providing environmentally friendly and sustainable benefits to people and communities.

children.label: nursing homes
children.definition: Facilities which provide nursing supervision and limited medical care to persons who do not require hospitalization.

children.label: biological specimen banks
children.definition: Facilities that collect, store, and distribute tissues, e.g., cell lines, microorganisms, blood, sperm, milk, breast tissue, for use by others. Other uses may include transplantation and comparison of diseased tissues in the identification of cancer.

children.label: semen banks
children.definition: Centers for acquiring, storing and distributing semen.

children.label: milk banks
children.definition: Centers for collecting, screening, storing, and distributing human milk donated by nursing mothers.

children.label: tissue banks
children.definition: Centers for acquiring, characterizing, and storing organs or tissue for future use.

children.label: gene banks
children.definition: The place where genetic material (cells, nucleic acids, etc.) is preserved. The main purpose is to conserve the DNA, RNA, genes, genome etc., for research or some other future use.

children.label: blood banks
children.definition: Centers for collecting the blood from donors; characterizing, storing and preserving blood or its components for future use.

children.label: bioeconomics
children.definition: A branch of economics which integrates the disciplines of biology and economics in order to explain economic activities on a biological basis and vice versa.

children.label: fungibility
children.definition: The characteristic of interchangeability of goods or assets with other individual goods or assets of the same type.

children.label: economic evaluation
children.definition: Comparison of two or more alternative courses of action in terms of both their costs and their consequences; economists usually distinguish several types of economic evaluation differing in how consequences are measured.

children.label: socioeconomics
children.definition: The branch of economics which examines the relationship between economic factors and society.

children.label: economic development
children.definition: Any effort or process that promotes the improvement of the economy of a region and the quality of life of its inhabitants.

children.label: sustainable development
children.definition: Economic development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.

children.label: sustainable agriculture
children.definition: An integrated system of plant and animal production practices having a site-specific application that will, over the long-termâ€” (A) satisfy human food and fiber needs; (B) enhance environmental quality and the natural resource base upon which the agriculture economy depends; (C) make the most efficient use of nonrenewable resources and on-farm resources and integrate, where appropriate, natural biological cycles and controls; (D) sustain the economic viability of farm operations; and (E) enhance the quality of life for farmers and society as a whole.

children.label: community supported agriculture
children.definition: Community Supported Agriculture consists of a community of individuals who pledge support to a farm operation so that the farmland becomes, either legally or spiritually, the community's farm, with the growers and consumers providing mutual support and sharing the risks and benefits of food production.

children.label: good agricultural practices
children.definition: Guidelines and methods for farmers, growers, food producers, and those involved in agriculture to manage the resources important to agriculture, such as soil, water, and air, to produce safe and hygienic food products with commitment to sustainability and conservation, while protecting human and animal health and welfare as well as the environment.

children.label: sustainable agricultural intensification
children.definition: Sustainable crop production intensification provides opportunities for optimizing crop production per unit area, taking into consideration the range of sustainability aspects including potential and/or real social, political, economic and environmental impacts.

children.label: crop diversification
children.definition: Crop diversification is defined as the strategy of shifting from less profitable to more profitable crops, changing of variety and cropping system, increasing exports and competitiveness in both domestic and international markets, protecting the environment, and making conditions favorable for combining Agriculture-Fishery-Forestry-Livestock. Crop diversification can be a useful means to increase crop output under different situations.

children.label: sustainable land management
children.definition: A process for the management of land resources that meets present needs without compromising future ecosystem services and land productivity.

children.label: sustainable communities
children.definition: A community that is environmentally, economically, and socially healthy and resilient through management of its natural, financial, and human resources to meet current needs while ensuring that sufficient resources are equitably available into the future.

children.label: developed countries
children.definition: Countries that have reached a level of economic achievement through an increase of production, per capita income and consumption, and utilization of natural and human resources.

children.label: developing countries
children.definition: Countries in the process of change directed toward economic growth, that is, an increase in production, per capita consumption, and income.

children.label: socioeconomic development
children.definition: Activities involving both social and economic factors which result in the growth of the economy and societal progress and is measureable in both economic and social terms, e.g., growth in the number of jobs created and increase in life expectancy.

children.label: stumpage
children.definition: Value of timber as it stands uncut, that is, uncut marketable timber.

children.label: limited liability partnership
children.definition: A partnership formed by two or more persons in which partners are statutorily provided full-shield protection from partnership liabilities, debts and obligations.

children.label: public-private partnerships
children.definition: A formal partnership between government (state, local or federal) and one or more private sector companies to persue a specific objective of interest to the government.

children.label: general partnership
children.definition: A business partnership in which two or more persons are co-owners of a business for profit.

children.label: limited partnership
children.definition: A business organization where a partnership is formed by two or more persons and has one or more general partners and one or more limited partners.

children.label: sole proprietorship
children.definition: A business organization where that business is owned and managed by one person.

children.label: corporations
children.definition: A for profit business organization where the corporation is a distinct entity from the people who control, manage and own it. Stockholders and company officials (e.g. board of directors) are protected from personal loss.

children.label: nonprofit corporations
children.definition: A business organization where the income or profit of the corporation is not distributed to corporation members, directors or officers.

children.label: agribusiness
children.definition: A business that earns revenue from agriculture.

children.label: business enterprises
children.definition: An organization engaged in the production, distribution and/or sale of goods or services in order to satisfy customer requirements and make a profit.

children.label: ranching
children.definition: Practice of raising livestock on large tracts of land.

children.label: farms
children.definition: Any establishment that normally produces and sells agricultural products.

children.label: commercial farms
children.definition: farms which produce crops and livestock primarily for sale.

children.label: small farms
children.definition: Farms with less than $250,000 gross receipts annually, on which day-to-day labor and management are provided by the farmer and/or the farm family that owns the production or owns, or leases, the productive assets.

children.label: family farms
children.definition: An agricultural business which (1) produces agricultural commodities for sale in such quantities so as to be recognized as a farm rather than a rural residence; (2) produces enough income (including off farm employment) to pay family and farm operating expenses, to pay debts, and to maintain the property; (3) is managed by the operator; (4) has a substantial amount of labor provided by the operator and family; and (5) may use seasonal labor during peak periods and a reasonable amount of full-time hired labor.

children.label: cash grain farms
children.definition: A farm where corn, grain sorghum, small grains, soybeans, or field peas and beans account for at least 50% of the value of farm products sold.

children.label: cooperatives
children.definition: An organization formed for the purpose of producing and marketing goods or products owned collectively by members who share in the benefits.

children.label: marketing cooperatives
children.definition: A type of cooperative which assemble and market commodities produced mostly by their members.

children.label: bargaining cooperatives
children.definition: A type of cooperative which negotiates price, quality, and delivery terms with buyers.

children.label: private enterprises
children.definition: Organizations engaged in the production, distribution and/or sale of goods or services and owned and operated by a single or group of private persons or institutions.

children.label: home-based businesses
children.definition: A small business which is based in a residence and is owned and operated by the resident of the home, although hired employees may perform work and live elsewhere.

children.label: privatization
children.definition: Process of shifting publicly controlled services and/or facilities to the private sector.

children.label: private sector
children.definition: That distinct portion of the institutional, industrial, or economic structure of a country that is controlled or owned by non-governmental, private interests.

children.label: leasing
children.definition: Contracting for the use and possession of land, buildings, etc., for a specified time and fixed payments.

children.label: operating leases
children.definition: A type of leasing contract in which the renter has temporary use of an asset and is not considered as the owner of the asset.

children.label: capital leases
children.definition: A type of leasing contract in which the renter has temporary use of an asset and is considered as the owner of the asset.

children.label: auctions
children.definition: Public sale of property in which bids are made by multiple parties; usually the property goes to the highest bidder.

children.label: marketing year
children.definition: The 12-month period beginning just after harvest during which a crop may be sold domestically, exported, or put into reserve stocks. Compare "crop year."
