children.label: marketing cooperatives
children.definition: A type of cooperative which assemble and market commodities produced mostly by their members.

children.label: sales
children.definition: Total products and services sold.

children.label: market prices
children.definition: A price at which a good or service is actually exchanged for another good or service (as an in-kind payment) or for money (in which case it is a financial price). A market price can refer to a transaction that occurs at any location, not necessarily a village or wholesale market. Distinguish from "shadow price".

children.label: shadow prices
children.definition: The value used in economic analysis for a cost or a benefit in a project when the market price is felt to be a poor estimate of economic value. Shadow price technically implies a price that has been derived from a complex mathematical model. Shadow prices are estimates of efficiency prices. For final goods and services, the shadow price is the value in use. For intermediate goods and services, the shadow price is the opportunity cost, the benefit foregone by using a scarce resource for one purpose instead of its next best alternative use.

children.label: health claims
children.definition: Any claim made on the label or in labeling of a food that expressly or by implication characterizes the relationship of any substance (e.g., a specific food or component of food) to a disease or health-related condition.

children.label: generic advertising
children.definition: The promotion of a particular commodity without reference to a specific producer, brand name or manufacturer. Producers join together to expand total demand for the commodity, thereby helping their own sales. These activities are often self-funded through assessments on marketings called check-off programs.

children.label: globalization
children.definition: The world-wide integration of markets for goods, services and capital.

children.label: markets
children.definition: A hypothetical construct of economic theory representing the place all potential buyers and sellers of all goods and services come together, express their desires and offer their wares, through bargaining establish a price structure and production schedule, and complete their transactions. In standard usage it refers to all locations where economic transactions occur treated as a single whole.

children.label: wet markets
children.definition: Wet market is a group of individual small food vendors in an open space within a street or multi-storied building where workers sell food such as fresh meat, fish, vegetables, fruits and meat animals.

children.label: grocery stores
children.definition: Stores that carry primarily food items with relatively small selections of non-food products such as cleaning products, paper goods, etc.

children.label: environmental markets
children.definition: An exchange-based approach to achieve pollution abatement goals set by environmental regulations that place a "cap" on emissions. A credit or offset is given to providers of pollution abatement. Regulated firms who cannot economically meet their abatement obligations can purchase credits from those who can produce credits at a cost lower than the expected market price.

children.label: supermarkets
children.definition: Large stores that routinely stock non-food related items such as toys, clothes, extensive selections of health care/pharmacy items, books and magazines, garden products, notions, etc. in addition to a wide variety of foods.

children.label: futures trading
children.definition: An agreement between two people, one who sells and agrees to deliver and one who buys and agrees to receive a certain kind, quality, and quantity of product to be delivered during a specified delivery month at a specified price.

children.label: economic analysis
children.definition: An analysis of the economic effects of a given action. It includes measurement of all pertinent desirable and undesirable consequences to all segments of the economy stated in comparable quantitative monetary terms. It also includes an objective or subjective analysis of factors not quantifiable in monetary terms.

children.label: economic valuation
children.definition: Estimating or appraising the worth of things having financial or monetary value, including property, assets, goods and services, etc.

children.label: contingent valuation
children.definition: A method of estimating the value people put on, usually, non-market goods or costs by surveying their willingness to pay to receive or avoid them.

children.label: market value
children.definition: Highest estimated price for an item to be sold in an open, competitive market that a buyer would pay and a seller would accept.

children.label: cost of illness analysis
children.definition: A determination of the economic impact of a disease or health condition, including treatment costs; this form of study does not address benefits/outcomes.

children.label: consumption (economics)
children.definition: The utilization of economic goods to satisfy needs or in manufacturing.

children.label: ex ante analysis
children.definition: Evaluation of economic values, such as prices, returns, gains, etc. which are made in advance of future events or uncertainties.

children.label: Consumer Price Index
children.definition: The Bureau of Labor Statistics' general measure of retail prices (for goods and services) paid by urban wage earners and clerical workers. Includes prices of about 400 items, including food, clothing, housing, medical care, and transportation. The CPI-U is commonly used to deflate time series data and is the most widely accepted measure of inflation.

children.label: cost benefit analysis
children.definition: An analytical technique that compares the costs and benefits of investments, program or policy actions in order to determine which alternative or alternatives maximize net benefits (economic efficiency).

children.label: econometrics
children.definition: The testing and quantifying of economic theories and the solution of economic problems by their conversion to mathematical forms, application of mathematical processes and the use of statistical techniques.

children.label: elasticities
children.definition: Measures of responsiveness of one economic variable to another.

children.label: supply elasticities
children.definition: The degree to which a price of a good changes as a result of a unit change in supply (= % change in quantity supplied / % change in price).

children.label: demand elasticities
children.definition: Relationships between the change in the price of a commodity and the corresponding change in the quantity that is sold. If a small change in price is accompanied by a relatively large change in the quantity sold, demand is said to be elastic (responsive to price changes). But if a large change in the price is accompanied by a small change in the quantity sold, demand is said to be inelastic.

children.label: elasticity of substitution
children.definition: A measurement of the effect on consumption of each of two goods if the price of the other changes.

children.label: income elasticities
children.definition: Relationships between the amount of goods demanded as income grows (= % change in quantity / % change in income).

children.label: consumer surplus
children.definition: In economics, the difference between the price that a consumer pays for a good or a service and the amount that he would be willing to pay rather than be deprived of the good or service.

children.label: production functions
children.definition: A mathematical relationship (frequently presented as a graph) which shows how inputs of various physical factors are related to changes of output - e.g., the effect of different amounts of fertilizer or thinning on the rate of timber production.

children.label: Almost Ideal Demand System
children.definition: A consumer demand model based on the flexible functional form approach, widely used in economics, to study and analyze consumer behavior.

children.label: bioeconomic models
children.definition: Models used to estimate and predict impacts of various agricultural and natural resource management strategies alterations on economic, environmental and sustainability objectives.

children.label: producer surplus
children.definition: In economics, the difference between the price that a producer sells a good or service at and the amount that he would be willing to accept in exchange for the good or service.

children.label: import quotas
children.definition: A quantitative limit placed on the importation of specific commodities.

children.label: market access
children.definition: The extent to which a good or a service can compete with locally-made products in another market.

children.label: trade agreements
children.definition: A negotiated agreement usually among two or more countries or regions to limit or alter their policies with respect to trade.

children.label: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
children.definition: A post- World War II international treaty for the regulation of trade policy and the reduction of tariffs and trade barriers which was subsumed into the World Trade Organization in 1995.

children.label: free trade
children.definition: A policy in international markets allowing unrestricted exchange of goods between countries without the imposition of special taxes and government interference.

children.label: export subsidies
children.definition: A direct or indirect compensation provided by governments to private commercial firms to promote exports of domestic products.

children.label: bulk commodities
children.definition: Generally, high volume, low value unprocessed agricultural commodities, which are treated as though they are homogeneous (fungible) in nature prior to processing. Grains, oilseeds, and cotton are considered bulk commodities. Contrasting categories are high value commodities, semiprocessed and processed commodities, and consumer ready commodities.

children.label: supply
children.definition: The amount of a good or service that will be offered for sale over a given range of prices at a particular point in time.

children.label: economic demand
children.definition: The desire to purchase economic goods or services at the market price.

children.label: tariffs
children.definition: Charges assessed by a government on imported items at their point of customs entry into the country, and paid for by the importer.

children.label: ad valorem duty
children.definition: Tariff defined as a percentage of the value of an imported commodity or product.

children.label: bound tariffs
children.definition: The most-favored-nation tariff resulting from negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and incorporated as the integral component of a country's schedule of concessions; a commitment not to raise a tariff above a specified level.

children.label: bankruptcy
children.definition: A legal process in which a debtor unable to pay debts has his assets liquidated and the debtor is relieved of further liability for those debts.

children.label: finance
children.definition: The management of money, banking, investments, debts, and credit.

children.label: discount rate
children.definition: A percentage that is used to adjust a forecast of expenditures to account for the time value of money or opportunity costs; it can be based on the utility's cost of capital.

children.label: excise tax
children.definition: Tax imposed on the manufacture and distribution of specific nonessential consumer goods, such as cigarettes and fuel.

children.label: estate tax
children.definition: Tax imposed on the transfer of property from a deceased person to his/her heirs, legatees or devisees.

children.label: sales tax
children.definition: Tax imposed on the retail price of an item which is collected by the retailer.

children.label: Farm Credit System
children.definition: A national network of lending cooperatives owned by their farmer and rancher borrowers.

children.label: funding
children.definition: Financial resources collected or provided for the support of a particular purpose.

children.label: interest (finance)
children.definition: The fee paid for the use of borrowed money, usually a percentage of the amount loaned.

children.label: stocks and shares
children.definition: A part of the ownership of a company which people buy as an investment. Each investor's ownership represents a piece of the corporation's assets and earnings.

children.label: natural capital
children.definition: The stock of natural resources, land and ecosystems that provides a flow of economically valuable goods or services into the future. Example: A forest (stock) may produce goods such as new trees for timber; and ecosystem services such as carbon sequestration, erosion control and wildlife habitat.

children.label: working conditions
children.definition: Use for the social, physical and psychological environment of human laborers.

children.label: telecommuting
children.definition: The use of computers and telecommunications technology to allow employees to perform some or all of a job at home.

children.label: livelihood
children.definition: An individual's capabilities, assets and activities required for supporting one's living.

children.label: labor force
children.definition: Employed persons and those looking for work.

children.label: migrant workers
children.definition: People who migrate from one section to another section of the same country or migrate to another country in order to find gainful employment.

children.label: labor productivity
children.definition: Output per unit of labor input.

children.label: farm labor
children.definition: People gainfully employed by a farm operator to assist with the farm work, including regular, seasonal, local, migratory, full-time or part-time employment.

children.label: child labor
children.definition: Employment of minors in work that deprives children of their childhood, potential, dignity, and is harmful to their physical and mental development.

children.label: employment
children.definition: The state of being engaged in an activity or service for wages or salary.

children.label: occupations
children.definition: General categories of job or work specializations, as characterized by duties, skill levels, status, pay, responsibility levels, or other distinguishing factors.

children.label: labor market
children.definition: Factors affecting the supply of and demand for workers.

children.label: labor unions
children.definition: Association of workers formed for the purpose of collective bargaining with employers for the benefit of the workers, such as wages, working conditions, etc.

children.label: agglomeration economies
children.definition: The benefits obtained when multiple companies are located near each other, due to decreased production costs and other advantages brought by network effects.

children.label: multipliers
children.definition: In macroeconomics, the proportionate increase in national income (in the form of consumption of final goods and services), that occurs from each unit increase in new spending from some "autonomous" source such as private investment, the government, or the outside world (through exports). The sum total of all additional consumption induced by the initial spending generally exceeds the amount of the initial spending itself. The quantitative measure of this additional consumption relative to the initial increase in investment spending is the multiplier. Many variants of the basic multiplier can be calculated.

children.label: economies of scale
children.definition: The increase in production efficiency as the number of goods being produced increases and production costs per unit decreases; may also apply to distribution of a service or in marketing.

children.label: market economy
children.definition: An economic system in which goods and services are exchanged in a market free from government regulation or direction, and production and consumption of goods and services is driven by consumer demand and producer supply.

children.label: collectivization
children.definition: Organizing an economy, industry or enterprise based on the political or economic theory of group control, especially over production and distribution.

children.label: centrally planned economy
children.definition: An economic system in which the economy is directed and administered by its government.

children.label: socialism
children.definition: An economic system that is regulated, directed and administered by the government rather than private enterprises and which supports the principle of equal distribution of wealth among individuals.

children.label: transitional economic systems
children.definition: An economic system which is changing from a system where the government directs and administers the production of goods and services to a system where goods and servces can be exchanged on a market free from governmental intevention.

children.label: mixed economy
children.definition: An economic system in which some goods and services are directed and administered by the government and some goods and services are privately owned and are exchanged in a free market.

children.label: demographic statistics
children.definition: Concept limited to the population statistics of any population.

children.label: Census of Agriculture
children.definition: A count taken every 5 years of the number of farms, land in farms, crop acreage and production, livestock numbers and production, farm expenses, farm facilities and equipment, farm tenure, value of farm products sold, farm size, type of farm, farm operator characteristics (age, race, sex), etc. Data are obtained for States and counties. USDA now administers the Census of Agriculture, which was previously done by the U.S. Bureau of the Census.

children.label: Census of Agriculture
children.definition: A count taken every 5 years of the number of farms, land in farms, crop acreage and production, livestock numbers and production, farm expenses, farm facilities and equipment, farm tenure, value of farm products sold, farm size, type of farm, farm operator characteristics (age, race, sex), etc. Data are obtained for States and counties. USDA now administers the Census of Agriculture, which was previously done by the U.S. Bureau of the Census.

children.label: environmental economics
children.definition: A branch of economics that studies the economic impact of environmental policies and uses economic analysis to inform environmental decision-making, as in the cost-benefit evaluation of environmental protection.

children.label: ecosystem services
children.definition: Benefits people and other organisms obtain from ecosystems; examples include: pure water and clean air, scenic landscapes, wildlife habitat and biodiversity.

children.label: ecological value
children.definition: The worth attributed to an organism, ecosystem, product, resource or activity, in terms of benefits to the environment.

children.label: stumpage
children.definition: Value of timber as it stands uncut, that is, uncut marketable timber.

children.label: land tenure
children.definition: The holding of land and the rights that go with such holding, including all forms of holding from fee simple title (embracing all possible rights within the general limitations imposed by the government) to the various forms of tenancy or holding of land owned by another.

children.label: cash rents
children.definition: Land or farm rents paid as a fixed amount of money, in contrast to renting for a share of the crop.

children.label: sharecropping
children.definition: A farm leasing agreement in which both landowner and tenant farmer receive a share of the harvested crop. The farmowner contributes farmland and farm buildings, whereas the tenant provides labor and equipment and usually resides on the farm. Both may share the cost of farm inputs such as seed, fertilizers and pesticides; the risk from variation in crop prices and yields is also shared, as compared with cash rents.

children.label: food law
children.definition: Laws and legislation that govern the quality, processing, packaging, labeling and safety of food, feeds and food products.

children.label: Food Quality Protection Act
children.definition: The Food Quality Protection Act was enacted on Aug. 3, 1996 to ensure the safety of food in the United States.

children.label: FDA Food Safety Modernization Act
children.definition: FSMA was signed into law by President Obama on January 4, 2011. It aims to ensure the U.S. food supply is safe by shifting the focus from responding to contamination to preventing it.

children.label: US Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act
children.definition: FALCPA is an amendment to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and requires that the label of a food that contains an ingredient that is or contains protein from a "major food allergen" declare the presence of the allergen in the manner described by the law.

children.label: jurisprudence
children.definition: The science, philosophy, and knowledge of law, rights, and customs of a locality so that justice can be administered.

children.label: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
Endangered Species Act of 1973
children.definition: Repeals and replaces the Endangered Species Conservation Act of 1969. An act to provide a means whereby ecosystems upon which endangered species and threatened species depend may be conserved, to provide a program for the conservation of such endangered species and threatened species, and to take such steps as may be appropriate to achieve the purposes of the (relevant) treaties and conventions.

children.label: sanitary and phytosanitary regulations
children.definition: Government standards to protect humans, animals and plants from diseases, pests or contaminants.

children.label: Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990
pesticide law
children.definition: Laws, legislation and regulations governing the manufacture, transport, distribution, sale, labeling, packaging, composition, disposal, safety, use and registration of pesticides.

children.label: Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act
Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994
marketing orders and agreements
children.definition: Orders and agreements allow producers to promote orderly marketing through collectively influencing the supply, demand, or price of a particular commodity so as to create orderly marketing. Research and promotion can be financed with pooled funds. Once approved by a required number of a commodity's producers-usually two-thirds-the marketing order is binding on all handlers of the commodity within the geographic area of regulation. It may limit the quantity of goods marketed, or establish the grade, size, maturity, or quality of the goods. Marketing orders have been established for milk, fruits, vegetables, and other commodities. Marketing agreements may contain more diversified provisions, but are enforceable only against those handlers who enter into the agreement. An order can be terminated when a majority of all producers favor its termination or when USDA determines that the order no longer serves its intended purpose.
